self_care_tips: Management depends on the type and cause.

- For AOM: Pain relief (acetaminophen, ibuprofen). Antibiotics may be prescribed by doctor, especially for younger children, severe symptoms, or if bacterial cause is likely (though many AOMs are viral and resolve without antibiotics - 'watchful waiting' may be an option).
- For OME: Often resolves on its own within a few months. If persistent and causing hearing loss or speech delay, ear tubes (myringotomy with ventilation tube insertion) may be recommended.
- For COM: Requires ENT management, often involving antibiotic ear drops, keeping ear dry, and sometimes surgery (e.g., tympanoplasty).
Apply a warm (not hot) compress or washcloth to the affected ear to help relieve pain.
Keep head elevated when resting if it helps comfort.
Avoid exposing children to secondhand smoke (increases risk of ear infections).
Ensure vaccinations (e.g., pneumococcal, flu) are up to date, as they can help prevent some ear infections.
If antibiotics are prescribed, complete the full course.

otosclerosis.emergency_advice: While otosclerosis itself is not an emergency, seek medical attention if you experience sudden, significant hearing loss, severe dizziness or vertigo, or other new/worsening ear symptoms. This is to rule out other acute conditions or complications.
otosclerosis.general_advice: Otosclerosis is a condition affecting the middle ear characterized by abnormal bone remodeling (growth) in the bones of the middle ear, primarily around the stapes (the smallest of the three tiny bones, also called the 'stirrup'). This abnormal bone growth causes the stapes to become fixed or 'stuck' in place, preventing it from vibrating properly in response to sound waves. This impairs the transmission of sound from the middle ear to the inner ear (cochlea), resulting in progressive conductive hearing loss (sound doesn't conduct efficiently). The hearing loss is often bilateral (affecting both ears, though may be asymmetrical) and typically starts in young adulthood (ages 15-45). Some people with otosclerosis also experience tinnitus (ringing or buzzing in the ears) and, less commonly, dizziness or balance problems if the inner ear structures are involved (cochlear otosclerosis, which can cause sensorineural hearing loss as well). The exact cause is unknown, but genetic factors play a significant role (often runs in families). It may also be influenced by hormonal factors (can worsen during pregnancy) or viral infections (e.g., measles - though this link is debated).
otosclerosis.when_to_see_doctor: If you notice progressive hearing loss or tinnitus, consult an audiologist and an ENT specialist. Diagnosis involves a hearing test (audiogram - typically shows conductive hearing loss, often with a characteristic 'Carhart's notch' at 2000 Hz on bone conduction), tympanometry (usually normal), and ruling out other causes of conductive hearing loss. A CT scan may sometimes be done.
self_care_tips: Management options depend on the severity of hearing loss and patient preference.
- Observation: If hearing loss is mild and not bothersome, no specific treatment may be needed other than regular hearing monitoring.
- Hearing aids: Very effective for conductive hearing loss caused by otosclerosis, by amplifying sound to overcome the impaired transmission.

- Surgical treatment (Stapedectomy or Stapedotomy): This is the primary surgical option to restore hearing. It involves removing all or part of the fixed stapes bone and replacing it with a tiny prosthetic device that allows sound vibrations to pass to the inner ear. This surgery has a high success rate in experienced hands but carries small risks (e.g., worsening hearing loss, dizziness, taste disturbance, facial nerve injury - rare).
- Sodium fluoride supplements: Sometimes suggested in an attempt to slow progression of cochlear otosclerosis, but evidence is limited and use is controversial.
Protect your ears from loud noise exposure, as this can cause additional sensorineural hearing loss unrelated to otosclerosis.
Discuss risks and benefits of treatment options thoroughly with your ENT specialist.
Regular hearing check-ups.

ovarian_cancer.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for acute, severe complications that can occur with advanced ovarian cancer: sudden, severe abdominal or pelvic pain; significant abdominal distension with difficulty breathing (from rapid fluid buildup - ascites, or bowel obstruction); persistent nausea and vomiting with inability to keep food/fluids down; or signs of bowel obstruction (no stool/gas, vomiting).
ovarian_cancer.general_advice: Ovarian cancer is cancer that begins in the ovaries, the female reproductive glands that produce eggs (ova) and hormones like estrogen and progesterone. There are several types of ovarian cancer, classified by the type of cell where they originate: 1) Epithelial ovarian cancer (most common): Arises from cells on the outer surface of the ovary. Subtypes include serous, mucinous, endometrioid, clear cell. 2) Germ cell tumors: Arise from egg-producing cells; more common in younger women, often highly treatable. 3) Stromal cell tumors: Arise from connective tissue cells that produce hormones; rare. Ovarian cancer is often diagnosed at a late stage because early symptoms are often vague, non-specific, or absent, and there is no effective routine screening test for the general population. When symptoms do occur, they can include: persistent abdominal bloating or swelling, pelvic or abdominal pain or pressure, difficulty eating or feeling full quickly, urinary symptoms (urgency or frequency), changes in bowel habits (constipation or diarrhea), fatigue, back pain, pain during intercourse, and unexplained weight loss or gain. Risk factors include: older age, family history of ovarian, breast, or colorectal cancer (especially with BRCA1/BRCA2 gene mutations or Lynch syndrome), personal history of breast cancer, endometriosis, never having been pregnant or having first pregnancy late, obesity, and possibly use of fertility drugs or hormone therapy after menopause (though links are complex). Oral contraceptive use is associated with a reduced risk.
ovarian_cancer.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience persistent, unexplained symptoms like bloating, pelvic/abdominal pain, or feeling full quickly (especially if new and occurring almost daily for more than a few weeks), consult your doctor or gynecologist. While these symptoms are often due to benign conditions, it's important to rule out ovarian cancer. Diagnosis involves a pelvic exam, transvaginal ultrasound, CT scan or MRI, blood tests (e.g., CA-125 tumor marker - can be elevated in ovarian cancer but also in many benign conditions, so not a reliable screening tool alone), and definitively, surgical exploration with biopsy or removal of suspicious tissue.
self_care_tips: Treatment depends on the type, stage, and grade of the cancer, as well as overall health. It's managed by a gynecologic oncologist and a multidisciplinary team.

- Surgery: Mainstay of treatment, often involves staging (to determine extent of spread) and cytoreductive surgery ('debulking' - removing as much visible tumor as possible). This typically includes hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (removal of uterus, tubes, ovaries), omentectomy, and lymph node sampling/removal.
- Chemotherapy: Often given after surgery (adjuvant) or sometimes before (neoadjuvant). Intravenous (IV) or sometimes intraperitoneal (IP) chemotherapy.
- Targeted therapy: e.g., PARP inhibitors (for BRCA-mutated or HRD-positive cancers), anti-angiogenic drugs (e.g., bevacizumab).
- Hormone therapy: May be used for some types (e.g., low-grade serous, stromal tumors).
- Radiation therapy: Less commonly used as primary treatment but may be used for palliative care.
Genetic counseling and testing are important, especially if there's a family history or if certain features suggest an inherited predisposition.
Maintain good nutrition and hydration, especially during treatment. A dietitian can help.
Manage treatment side effects with your team's support.
Seek emotional, psychological, and social support (counseling, support groups).
Regular follow-up care is crucial for monitoring for recurrence.

ovarian_cyst.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for: sudden, severe abdominal or pelvic pain (especially if sharp, one-sided, and accompanied by nausea, vomiting, fever, or fainting). This could indicate a ruptured ovarian cyst (especially if large or hemorrhagic), ovarian torsion (twisting of the ovary, cutting off blood supply - a surgical emergency), or bleeding from a cyst. Also, if a known cyst causes acute, severe symptoms.
ovarian_cyst.general_advice: An ovarian cyst is a fluid-filled sac or pocket that develops on or within an ovary. They are very common, especially during a woman's reproductive years, and many are benign (non-cancerous) and cause no symptoms. Many ovarian cysts are 'functional,' meaning they form as part of the normal menstrual cycle: 1) Follicular cysts: Form when a follicle (sac where an egg develops) doesn't rupture to release the egg but continues to grow. 2) Corpus luteum cysts: Form after an egg is released, if the remaining follicular sac (corpus luteum) fills with fluid or blood. These functional cysts usually disappear on their own within 1-3 menstrual cycles. Other types of benign cysts include: Dermoid cysts (teratomas - can contain various tissues like hair, skin, teeth), Cystadenomas (can be filled with watery or mucousy fluid, can grow large), and Endometriomas ('chocolate cysts' - form from endometrial tissue in endometriosis). Most ovarian cysts are asymptomatic. When symptoms do occur, they can include: dull ache or sharp pain in the lower abdomen or pelvis (often one-sided), feeling of fullness or pressure in abdomen, bloating, pain during intercourse, painful bowel movements, or changes in menstrual cycle (irregular periods, heavier/lighter bleeding). Large cysts can sometimes cause ovarian torsion.
ovarian_cyst.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience persistent pelvic pain, bloating, or other concerning symptoms, or if a cyst is found during a routine pelvic exam or ultrasound, consult your doctor or gynecologist. They can determine the type and size of the cyst (usually with a pelvic ultrasound - transvaginal or abdominal) and recommend appropriate management. Blood tests (e.g., CA-125) may be done if there's concern about cancer, especially in postmenopausal women or if cyst has suspicious features, but CA-125 can be elevated in many benign conditions too.
self_care_tips: Management depends on the type, size, appearance of the cyst, symptoms, and patient's age.
- Observation ('watchful waiting'): Many functional cysts and small, simple, asymptomatic benign cysts resolve on their own. Follow-up ultrasounds may be done to monitor.
- Pain relief: Over-the-counter pain relievers (acetaminophen, NSAIDs) for mild discomfort.
- Hormonal contraceptives (e.g., birth control pills): May be prescribed to help prevent the formation of new functional cysts, but do not shrink existing ones.

- Surgery (laparoscopy or laparotomy): May be recommended if a cyst is large (e.g., >5-10 cm), persistent, causing significant symptoms, suspicious for malignancy, or if complications like torsion or rupture occur. Surgery can involve removing just the cyst (cystectomy, preserving the ovary) or removing the entire ovary (oophorectomy).
Apply a heating pad to the lower abdomen for pain.
Be aware of symptoms of potential complications (torsion, rupture) and seek care if they occur.
Regular gynecological check-ups.

ovarian_torsion.emergency_advice: Ovarian torsion is a gynecological emergency requiring immediate surgical intervention to save the ovary and fallopian tube. Seek immediate emergency medical attention if you experience: sudden onset of severe, sharp, unilateral (one-sided) lower abdominal or pelvic pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The pain may be constant or intermittent (if torsion is partial or twists/untwists). Fever may sometimes occur. Delay in treatment can lead to loss of blood supply to the ovary (ischemia), ovarian necrosis (tissue death), infection, and loss of the ovary.
ovarian_torsion.general_advice: Ovarian torsion is the twisting of an ovary around its supporting ligaments (infundibulopelvic ligament and utero-ovarian ligament), which also contain its blood supply. This twisting can cut off blood flow to the ovary and sometimes the fallopian tube (adnexal torsion). It can occur at any age but is more common during reproductive years. Risk factors that make an ovary more prone to twisting include: presence of an ovarian cyst or tumor (benign or malignant - especially those >5 cm, as they make the ovary heavier and less stable), pregnancy (ovary is enlarged, ligaments are lax), ovulation induction (for fertility treatments, can cause ovarian hyperstimulation and large cysts), previous ovarian torsion, or long ovarian ligaments. Symptoms are often acute and severe (see emergency advice).
ovarian_torsion.when_to_see_doctor: Go to the nearest emergency department immediately if ovarian torsion is suspected. Diagnosis involves a pelvic exam (may reveal adnexal tenderness or mass), and crucially, a pelvic ultrasound with Doppler study (to assess blood flow to the ovary - absent or reduced flow is a key sign, though normal flow doesn't entirely rule out intermittent torsion). CT or MRI may sometimes be used.
self_care_tips: Self-care is not for managing ovarian torsion; it requires urgent surgery.
Emergency surgical treatment (usually laparoscopic) is needed to:
- Untwist (detorse) the ovary and fallopian tube to restore blood supply.
- Assess ovarian viability. If the ovary appears viable, it is usually preserved.

- If there's an ovarian cyst or mass that contributed to the torsion, it may be removed (cystectomy) or the entire ovary may need to be removed (oophorectomy) if the ovary is necrotic or if the mass is suspicious.
- Oophoropexy (fixing the ovary to pelvic structures) may sometimes be done to prevent recurrence, especially if the other ovary is also at risk or if torsion is recurrent.
Pain management will be provided in the hospital.
Recovery depends on the type of surgery and extent of any damage. Follow all post-operative instructions.

overflow_incontinence.emergency_advice: While overflow incontinence itself is not usually an acute emergency, seek urgent medical attention if it's associated with acute urinary retention (sudden inability to urinate despite a full bladder, causing severe pain), or if there are signs of kidney damage or severe UTI (e.g., fever, chills, back pain, blood in urine) due to chronic urinary retention.
overflow_incontinence.general_advice: Overflow incontinence is a type of urinary incontinence characterized by the involuntary leakage of small amounts of urine from a bladder that is overly full and not emptying properly. It occurs when the bladder muscle (detrusor) is underactive or weak, or when there is a blockage (obstruction) at the bladder outlet that prevents complete emptying. Because the bladder doesn't empty well, it becomes distended, and pressure builds up until it exceeds the urethra's ability to hold back urine, leading to frequent or constant dribbling or leakage. Individuals may also experience a weak or hesitant urine stream, difficulty starting urination, straining to urinate, a feeling of incomplete bladder emptying, and needing to urinate frequently, including at night (nocturia). Common causes include: 1) Bladder outlet obstruction: e.g., benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer in men, urethral strictures, severe pelvic organ prolapse in women. 2) Weak bladder muscle (detrusor underactivity/atony): e.g., due to nerve damage (neurogenic bladder from diabetes, spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's), certain medications (e.g., anticholinergics, some antidepressants, muscle relaxants), or chronic overdistension of the bladder.
overflow_incontinence.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience symptoms of overflow incontinence, consult your doctor (primary care or urologist). It's important to identify the underlying cause. Diagnosis involves a medical history, physical exam (including pelvic/rectal exam), post-void residual (PVR) measurement (to check how much urine is left in bladder after voiding - often high in overflow incontinence), urinalysis, and sometimes urodynamic studies or imaging.
self_care_tips: Management depends on the underlying cause and aims to improve bladder emptying and reduce leakage.
- Treat bladder outlet obstruction: e.g., medications or surgery for BPH, dilation for strictures, pessary or surgery for prolapse.
- For weak bladder muscle:
- Timed voiding: Urinating on a regular schedule (e.g., every 2-4 hours) whether you feel the urge or not, to prevent bladder overfilling.
- Double voiding: After urinating, wait a few minutes and try to urinate again to empty more completely.
- Intermittent self-catheterization (ISC): Regularly draining the bladder with a thin tube. This is often a very effective management strategy for detrusor underactivity.
- Medications to help bladder contraction (e.g., bethanechol) are sometimes tried but have limited effectiveness and potential side effects.
- Indwelling catheter (Foley or suprapubic): May be used in some cases if other methods are not feasible or effective.
Review medications with your doctor to see if any might be contributing.
Avoid bladder irritants (caffeine, alcohol) if they worsen urgency/frequency.
Manage constipation, as a full rectum can put pressure on the bladder.
Use absorbent pads or products for leakage if needed while managing the underlying cause.

pain_after_an_operation.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention if postoperative pain is suddenly much worse, is not relieved by prescribed pain medication, or is accompanied by: signs of severe infection (high fever, chills, spreading redness/swelling/pus from incision); signs of a blood clot/DVT (swelling, redness, pain in calf/leg) or pulmonary embolism (sudden shortness of breath, chest pain); uncontrolled bleeding from incision; or other new, severe, or concerning symptoms. Pain out of proportion to the expected recovery could indicate a serious complication.
pain_after_an_operation.general_advice: Pain after an operation (postoperative pain) is a normal and expected occurrence as the body heals from surgical trauma. The intensity, duration, and type of pain vary greatly depending on the type and extent of surgery, individual pain tolerance, and pain management strategies used. Pain can be acute (immediately after surgery, gradually subsiding) or can sometimes become chronic (persistent pain lasting months after surgery). Effective pain management is crucial not only for comfort but also to promote faster recovery, encourage early mobilization (reducing risk of complications like blood clots or pneumonia), improve sleep, and reduce stress.
pain_after_an_operation.when_to_see_doctor: It's important to communicate with your surgical team (surgeon, anesthesiologist, nurses) about your pain levels both in the hospital and after discharge. If your pain is not well-controlled with the prescribed medication, if it suddenly worsens, or if you have concerns, contact your doctor. They can adjust your pain management plan or investigate for potential complications.
self_care_tips: Pain management is guided by your medical team.

- Take prescribed pain medications (e.g., opioids, NSAIDs, acetaminophen, local anesthetics via nerve blocks or epidurals) as directed. Don't wait until pain becomes severe before taking medication. Take it on a regular schedule if advised, especially in the early postoperative period.

- Be aware of potential side effects of pain medications (e.g., constipation, nausea, drowsiness with opioids) and discuss management with your doctor (e.g., stool softeners for opioid-induced constipation).
- Non-pharmacological pain relief methods can be helpful adjuncts:
- Ice packs or cold therapy (as directed) to reduce swelling and numb pain, especially for orthopedic surgeries.
- Heat therapy (later in recovery, for muscle soreness - check with doctor first).
- Positioning and support (e.g., using pillows to support injured area).
- Gentle movement and early mobilization (walking) as advised by your doctor/physical therapist; this can actually help reduce pain and prevent stiffness/complications.
- Relaxation techniques, deep breathing exercises, distraction (music, TV, reading).
Follow all post-operative instructions regarding wound care, activity restrictions, and when to resume normal activities.
Get adequate rest and nutrition to support healing.
Report any signs of complications promptly.
If pain persists beyond the expected healing period (chronic postoperative pain), discuss further evaluation and management options with your doctor (may involve referral to a pain specialist).

pain_disorder_affecting_the_neck.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention if neck pain is associated with: significant trauma (e.g., car accident, fall); sudden severe headache; fever, stiff neck with inability to touch chin to chest (could be meningitis); progressive neurological symptoms (weakness, numbness, or paralysis in arms or legs); loss of bladder or bowel control; or severe pain radiating down an arm that is new or rapidly worsening. (This is similar to 'Cervical Disorder' emergency advice).
pain_disorder_affecting_the_neck.general_advice: Neck pain disorder, or cervicalgia, is a general term for pain located in the neck region, which can also involve stiffness and limited range of motion. It's a very common problem. Causes are diverse and can include: 1) Muscle strain or sprain (most common): From poor posture (e.g., 'text neck' from looking down at phones/computers), sleeping in an awkward position, overuse, or minor injuries (e.g., whiplash). 2) Degenerative conditions: Cervical spondylosis (age-related wear and tear/arthritis of neck vertebrae and discs), degenerative disc disease. 3) Nerve compression: Herniated cervical disc or bone spurs (osteophytes) pressing on nerve roots (cervical radiculopathy - causing pain/numbness/weakness radiating into arm/hand) or spinal cord (cervical myelopathy - more widespread neurological symptoms). 4) Injuries: Whiplash, fractures (see separate entry). 5) Other conditions: Rheumatoid arthritis, fibromyalgia, meningitis (infection of brain/spinal cord membranes), tumors (rare). Sometimes, pain can be referred from other areas (e.g., shoulder).
pain_disorder_affecting_the_neck.when_to_see_doctor: Consult a doctor if neck pain is severe, persistent (lasts more than a few weeks despite self-care), recurrent, associated with radiating arm symptoms, or accompanied by neurological deficits or 'red flag' symptoms (see emergency advice). They can help determine the cause and recommend appropriate management.
self_care_tips: For mild to moderate acute neck pain (e.g., muscle strain):
- Rest and activity modification: Avoid activities that worsen pain for a day or two, then gradually resume activity. Avoid prolonged static postures.
- Ice or heat: Apply cold packs for first 24-48 hours (15-20 minutes at a time) for inflammation, then heat (heating pad, warm shower/bath) may be more soothing for muscle soreness/stiffness.
- Over-the-counter pain relievers: Acetaminophen, NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen), or topical pain relievers.
- Gentle stretching and range-of-motion exercises for the neck (as pain allows, e.g., slowly tilting head side to side, ear to shoulder, chin to chest). Avoid forceful or jerky movements.
- Maintain good posture: When sitting, standing, and using computers/phones. Ensure ergonomic setup of workstation.
- Use a supportive pillow for sleeping that keeps neck in a neutral alignment (avoid sleeping on stomach).
- Manage stress, as it can contribute to muscle tension.
Physical therapy can be very helpful for many types of neck pain, providing exercises, manual therapy, and education on posture/ergonomics.

Medical treatments (if conservative measures fail) may include: prescription medications (muscle relaxants, stronger pain relievers, neuropathic pain drugs), trigger point injections, epidural steroid injections, or rarely, surgery for specific conditions like severe herniated disc or spinal cord compression.

pancreatic_cancer.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for acute complications: severe, unrelenting abdominal or back pain; jaundice (yellowing of skin/eyes) with fever and chills (could be biliary obstruction with infection/cholangitis); persistent vomiting with inability to keep food/fluids down (could be duodenal or gastric outlet obstruction from tumor); signs of a blood clot/DVT/PE (pancreatic cancer increases risk); or severe gastrointestinal bleeding (rare unless tumor erodes into vessels).
pancreatic_cancer.general_advice: Pancreatic cancer is cancer that begins in the cells of the pancreas, an organ located behind the stomach that produces digestive enzymes and hormones like insulin. The most common type (about 90%) is pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), which arises from cells lining the pancreatic ducts. Neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas (PNETs or islet cell tumors) are less common and often have a better prognosis. Pancreatic cancer is often diagnosed at a late stage because early symptoms are often vague, non-specific, or absent, and it tends to be aggressive and spread early. Symptoms, when they occur, can include: abdominal pain (often in upper abdomen, may radiate to back, can be dull or gnawing, sometimes worse after eating or when lying down), unexplained significant weight loss, loss of appetite, jaundice (if tumor blocks bile duct - causing yellow skin/eyes, dark urine, pale stools, itching), changes in bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, oily/greasy stools - steatorrhea if pancreatic enzymes are blocked), nausea, vomiting, new-onset diabetes (especially in older adults with weight loss), fatigue, and depression. Risk factors include: smoking (major risk factor), obesity, chronic pancreatitis, diabetes (long-standing type 2, or new-onset), family history of pancreatic cancer or certain genetic syndromes (e.g., BRCA mutations, Lynch syndrome, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome), older age, and possibly high intake of red/processed meats or heavy alcohol use.
pancreatic_cancer.when_to_see_doctor: If you have persistent, unexplained symptoms suggestive of pancreatic cancer, especially jaundice, significant weight loss, or new-onset abdominal/back pain, consult your doctor promptly. Diagnosis involves imaging (CT scan, MRI/MRCP, endoscopic ultrasound - EUS), blood tests (liver function, tumor markers like CA 19-9 - not specific enough for screening but can be useful for monitoring), and often a biopsy (e.g., via EUS or CT-guided) to confirm cancer and determine type.
self_care_tips: Treatment depends on the type, stage, location of the cancer, and patient's overall health. It's managed by a multidisciplinary team (surgeon, medical oncologist, radiation oncologist, gastroenterologist, palliative care specialist).

- Surgery: The only potentially curative option, but only possible if cancer is localized and resectable (e.g., Whipple procedure - pancreaticoduodenectomy, or distal pancreatectomy). Many are unresectable at diagnosis.

- Chemotherapy: Often used before surgery (neoadjuvant), after surgery (adjuvant), or as primary treatment for advanced/metastatic disease. Common regimens include FOLFIRINOX or gemcitabine-based combinations.
- Radiation therapy: May be used with chemotherapy (chemoradiation), especially for locally advanced, unresectable tumors, or for palliative symptom relief.
- Targeted therapy or immunotherapy: Options for a small subset of patients with specific genetic mutations or biomarkers.

- Palliative care and symptom management are crucial throughout the course of illness: Pain control (can be severe), management of jaundice (e.g., biliary stenting), pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT) if exocrine insufficiency, nutritional support (dietitian consultation, supplements, sometimes feeding tubes), management of diabetes, and psychosocial support.
Quit smoking.
Maintain best possible nutrition and hydration.
Seek emotional and psychological support (counseling, support groups) for patient and family. Pancreatic cancer has a challenging prognosis.

panic_attack.emergency_advice: While a panic attack itself is not life-threatening, its symptoms can mimic serious medical conditions like a heart attack or respiratory distress. Seek immediate emergency medical attention if you are unsure if it's a panic attack or a medical emergency, especially if you have: severe chest pain, difficulty breathing, feeling of choking, fainting, or if it's your first severe attack. Also, if panic attacks are leading to suicidal thoughts or inability to function.
panic_attack.general_advice: A panic attack is a sudden episode of intense fear or discomfort that peaks within minutes and is accompanied by a range of physical and psychological symptoms. These attacks can occur unexpectedly (out of the blue) or can be cued by specific situations or triggers. Symptoms can include: palpitations, pounding heart, or accelerated heart rate; sweating; trembling or shaking; sensations of shortness of breath or smothering; feeling of choking; chest pain or discomfort; nausea or abdominal distress; feeling dizzy, unsteady, lightheaded, or faint; chills or heat sensations; paresthesias (numbness or tingling sensations); derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (being detached from oneself); fear of losing control or 'going crazy'; and fear of dying. Panic attacks can be very frightening and can lead to avoidance of situations where attacks have occurred or where escape might be difficult.
panic_attack.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience panic attacks, especially if they are recurrent, unexpected, or causing significant distress or impairment (e.g., leading to avoidance behaviors or development of Panic Disorder - see separate entry), consult a doctor or mental health professional (psychiatrist, psychologist, therapist). They can diagnose panic attacks/disorder, rule out underlying medical conditions that can mimic symptoms (e.g., thyroid problems, heart conditions, hypoglycemia), and recommend effective treatments.
self_care_tips: During a panic attack:
- Recognize that you are having a panic attack and that the symptoms, though terrifying, are not physically dangerous and will pass (usually peak within 10-20 minutes).

- Practice slow, deep breathing (diaphragmatic breathing): Inhale slowly through nose, hold for a few seconds, exhale slowly through mouth. This can help counteract hyperventilation which often accompanies panic.
- Grounding techniques: Focus on your senses (what you can see, hear, touch, smell, taste) to bring yourself back to the present moment. Name objects around you.
- Ride it out: Don't fight the feelings; accept them as temporary sensations.
- If possible, stay in the situation rather than fleeing, as avoidance can reinforce fear.
Long-term management and prevention (often with professional help):

- Psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is highly effective, involving identifying and challenging anxious thoughts, learning coping skills, and gradual exposure to feared situations or physical sensations associated with panic.

- Medications: Antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs) are often used for long-term prevention of panic attacks. Benzodiazepines may be prescribed for short-term, occasional use for severe acute attacks, but have risks of dependence.
- Lifestyle: Regular exercise, adequate sleep, stress management techniques (yoga, meditation, mindfulness), limit caffeine and alcohol, avoid illicit drugs.
- Identify and manage personal triggers for panic if any.

panic_disorder.emergency_advice: Same as for Panic Attack: Seek immediate emergency medical attention if unsure if it's a panic attack or a medical emergency (especially with chest pain, difficulty breathing), or if panic disorder is leading to suicidal thoughts or inability to function.
panic_disorder.general_advice: Panic disorder is an anxiety disorder characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks (see Panic Attack entry for symptoms of an individual attack) AND persistent concern or worry about having additional panic attacks or their consequences (e.g., losing control, having a heart attack, 'going crazy'), and/or a significant maladaptive change in behavior related to the attacks (e.g., avoidance of situations or places where attacks have occurred or where escape might be difficult - this can lead to agoraphobia). The panic attacks are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition, and are not better explained by another mental disorder. Panic disorder can be very debilitating and significantly impact a person's quality of life, leading to avoidance of many situations and social isolation.
panic_disorder.when_to_see_doctor: If you are experiencing recurrent, unexpected panic attacks and have developed a persistent fear of having more attacks or are avoiding situations due to this fear, consult a doctor or mental health professional (psychiatrist, psychologist, therapist). Effective treatments are available.
self_care_tips: Professional treatment is key for Panic Disorder.
- Psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), particularly including exposure techniques (to feared situations or physical sensations of panic), is highly effective.

- Medications: Antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs) are often first-line for long-term management. Benzodiazepines may be used short-term or for occasional severe attacks, but with caution due to dependence risk.
Learn about panic disorder and panic attacks to understand what is happening.
Practice coping skills learned in therapy (e.g., breathing exercises, cognitive restructuring, grounding techniques) during panic attacks and when feeling anxious.
Gradually confront feared situations (as part of ERP in therapy).
Lifestyle: Regular exercise, adequate sleep, stress management, limit caffeine/alcohol, avoid illicit drugs.
Build a strong support system.
Support groups for anxiety/panic disorder can be helpful.
Be patient and persistent with treatment.

parasitic_disease.emergency_advice: Emergency needs depend on the specific parasite and severity of infection. Seek immediate medical attention for: signs of severe systemic illness (high fever, chills, sepsis); severe dehydration from profuse diarrhea/vomiting; bloody diarrhea; significant neurological symptoms (seizures, coma, severe headache - e.g., with cerebral malaria or neurocysticercosis); severe respiratory distress; or signs of organ damage or obstruction caused by parasites (e.g., biliary obstruction, intestinal obstruction, severe anemia).
parasitic_disease.general_advice: Parasitic disease is an infectious disease caused or transmitted by a parasite. A parasite is an organism that lives on or in a host organism and gets its food from or at the expense of its host. There are three main classes of parasites that can cause disease in humans: 1) Protozoa: Microscopic, single-celled organisms (e.g., Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Entamoeba histolytica - causing intestinal infections; Plasmodium - causing malaria; Toxoplasma gondii - causing toxoplasmosis; Trypanosomes - causing African sleeping sickness or Chagas disease). 2) Helminths: Multicellular parasitic worms (e.g., roundworms like Ascaris, hookworms, pinworms; tapeworms like Taenia; flukes like Schistosoma). 3) Ectoparasites: Organisms that live on the skin (e.g., lice, scabies mites, ticks, fleas). Parasitic diseases are a major public health problem worldwide, especially in tropical and subtropical regions with poor sanitation and hygiene. Transmission can occur through contaminated food or water, insect vectors (e.g., mosquitoes, ticks), direct contact, or penetration of skin. Symptoms are extremely diverse depending on the parasite, site of infection, and host immune response, ranging from asymptomatic to mild digestive upset, skin rashes, to severe, life-threatening systemic illness.
parasitic_disease.when_to_see_doctor: If you suspect a parasitic infection, especially if you have traveled to or live in an endemic area, or have relevant exposures and develop symptoms (e.g., persistent diarrhea, abdominal pain, unexplained fever, skin lesions, fatigue, weight loss), consult your doctor (primary care, infectious disease specialist, or travel medicine specialist). Diagnosis involves identifying the parasite or its eggs/cysts in stool, blood, tissue samples, or through serological tests (for antibodies) or molecular tests (PCR).
self_care_tips: Treatment is specific to the diagnosed parasitic infection and involves antiparasitic medications (e.g., antiprotozoal drugs like metronidazole, paromomycin; antihelminthic drugs like albendazole, mebendazole, praziquantel; antimalarials; topical treatments for ectoparasites). Take all medication as prescribed for the full course.
Supportive care: Manage symptoms like diarrhea (hydration with ORS), fever, pain. Ensure good nutrition.
Prevention is crucial:
- Practice good personal hygiene: Wash hands frequently with soap and water, especially after using toilet, changing diapers, before preparing/eating food.

- Safe food and water practices: Drink safe (bottled, boiled, filtered) water, especially when traveling. Wash fruits/vegetables thoroughly or peel them. Cook food (especially meat, fish, poultry) to safe temperatures. Avoid raw or undercooked foods in high-risk areas.
- Proper sanitation and waste disposal.
- Vector control: Protect against insect bites (repellents, bed nets, protective clothing) in areas where vector-borne parasites are prevalent.
- Avoid walking barefoot in areas where soil-transmitted helminths are common.
- For travelers, seek pre-travel advice on risks and preventive measures (including prophylactic medications if needed, e.g., for malaria).

parathyroid_adenoma.emergency_advice: While parathyroid adenoma itself is not usually an acute emergency, seek immediate medical attention for symptoms of a hypercalcemic crisis (severe hypercalcemia - see Hypercalcemia entry), which can be a complication: severe nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, confusion, lethargy, coma, arrhythmias, or acute kidney failure. Also, if there are complications like pathological fractures due to severe bone disease.
parathyroid_adenoma.general_advice: A parathyroid adenoma is a benign (non-cancerous) tumor of one (most commonly) or more of the parathyroid glands. Humans typically have four small parathyroid glands located in the neck, behind or near the thyroid gland. These glands produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a key role in regulating calcium, phosphorus, and vitamin D levels in the blood and bones. A parathyroid adenoma causes the affected gland(s) to become overactive and produce too much PTH, leading to primary hyperparathyroidism. This results in high blood calcium levels (hypercalcemia) and often low or inappropriately normal blood phosphorus levels. Most parathyroid adenomas are sporadic (occur by chance), but they can rarely be part of genetic syndromes (e.g., Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia - MEN). Many people with mild primary hyperparathyroidism due to an adenoma have no symptoms, and it's found incidentally on routine blood tests. When symptoms do occur (often due to chronic hypercalcemia), they can be remembered by 'stones, bones, groans, and psychiatric overtones': Kidney stones (nephrolithiasis), Bone pain, osteoporosis, fractures, Abdominal groans (constipation, nausea, vomiting, peptic ulcers, pancreatitis), and Psychiatric overtones (fatigue, weakness, depression, anxiety, memory problems, confusion, lethargy). Other symptoms can include excessive thirst and urination, and high blood pressure.
parathyroid_adenoma.when_to_see_doctor: If you have symptoms suggestive of hyperparathyroidism or if high calcium/PTH levels are found on blood tests, consult your doctor (primary care or endocrinologist/endocrine surgeon). Diagnosis involves blood tests (calcium, PTH, vitamin D, phosphorus, kidney function), urine tests (24-hour urine calcium), bone density scan (DXA), and imaging to locate the adenoma(s) (e.g., parathyroid ultrasound, sestamibi scan, 4D-CT scan).
self_care_tips: Treatment depends on the severity of hyperparathyroidism, symptoms, and presence of complications.

- Surgical removal of the affected parathyroid gland(s) (parathyroidectomy): This is the primary and usually curative treatment for symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism or for asymptomatic individuals who meet certain criteria (e.g., very high calcium, significant bone loss, kidney stones, young age). Minimally invasive parathyroidectomy (MIP) is often possible if the adenoma is localized preoperatively.

- Observation ('watchful waiting'): For individuals with mild, asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism who don't meet criteria for surgery, regular monitoring of calcium levels, kidney function, and bone density may be an option.

- Medications: Cinacalcet (a calcimimetic) can lower PTH and calcium levels and may be used for some patients who are not surgical candidates or have parathyroid carcinoma (rare). Bisphosphonates may be used to treat osteoporosis.
Stay well-hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids (helps prevent kidney stones).
Ensure adequate (but not excessive) calcium and vitamin D intake through diet, as per doctor's advice (paradoxically, severe restriction can sometimes stimulate PTH further).
Engage in regular weight-bearing exercise to support bone health.
Avoid medications that can raise calcium levels (e.g., thiazide diuretics, lithium) if possible, unless discussed with doctor.
Follow up regularly with your endocrinologist for monitoring.

parkinson_disease.emergency_advice: While PD is a chronic, progressive disorder, seek urgent medical attention for acute complications: sudden, severe worsening of motor symptoms or 'off' periods (when medication isn't working well); severe falls leading to injury; acute psychosis or hallucinations (can be medication side effect or disease progression); severe swallowing difficulties leading to choking or aspiration pneumonia; or signs of severe infection (PD patients can be at higher risk). Also, if there are thoughts of self-harm or suicide due to depression or distress from the disease.
parkinson_disease.general_advice: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects dopamine-producing neurons in a specific area of the brain called the substantia nigra. Dopamine is a neurotransmitter crucial for controlling movement, as well as mood and motivation. The loss of these dopamine cells leads to the characteristic motor (movement-related) symptoms of PD. Key motor symptoms include: 1) Tremor: Often a resting tremor (shaking that occurs when limb is at rest, may improve with movement), commonly starting in one hand or fingers ('pill-rolling' tremor). 2) Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement, difficulty initiating movement. 3) Rigidity: Stiffness of limbs, neck, or trunk. 4) Postural instability: Impaired balance and coordination, leading to increased risk of falls (usually a later symptom). Other motor symptoms can include shuffling gait, freezing of gait, masked facies (reduced facial expression), micrographia (small handwriting), and speech changes (soft, monotone voice - hypophonia). PD also involves non-motor symptoms, which can be very bothersome and may precede motor symptoms. These include: loss of smell (anosmia), sleep disturbances (e.g., REM sleep behavior disorder - acting out dreams, insomnia), constipation, depression, anxiety, fatigue, cognitive impairment (e.g., problems with attention, executive function, memory - can progress to Parkinson's disease dementia in later stages), and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, urinary problems, sweating abnormalities). The exact cause of PD is unknown, but involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Age is a major risk factor.
parkinson_disease.when_to_see_doctor: If you develop symptoms suggestive of Parkinson's disease, consult a doctor (primary care or neurologist, preferably one specializing in movement disorders). Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on medical history, neurological exam (assessing for characteristic motor signs), and response to dopaminergic medication. There is no definitive blood test or imaging scan to diagnose PD, though imaging (e.g., MRI, DaTscan) may be used to rule out other conditions or support diagnosis in some cases.
self_care_tips: While there is no cure for PD, treatments can help manage symptoms and improve quality of life. Management is multidisciplinary.
- Medications: Mainstay of treatment to increase dopamine levels or mimic its effects.
- Levodopa (often combined with carbidopa, e.g., Sinemet): Most effective drug for motor symptoms, converted to dopamine in brain.
- Dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine patch): Mimic dopamine effects.
- MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline, rasagiline): Help prevent breakdown of dopamine.
- COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone): Prolong effect of levodopa.
- Amantadine: Can help with dyskinesia (involuntary movements, a side effect of long-term levodopa).
- Medications for non-motor symptoms (e.g., antidepressants, sleep aids, cognitive enhancers).
- Therapies:
- Physical therapy: Crucial for improving balance, gait, flexibility, strength (e.g., LSVT BIG program).
- Occupational therapy: To help with daily living skills and adaptations.
- Speech therapy: For voice problems (e.g., LSVT LOUD program) and swallowing difficulties.
- Lifestyle:
- Regular exercise: Very important (aerobic, strength, balance, flexibility - e.g., boxing, dancing, Tai Chi).
- Healthy diet: Balanced, high-fiber (for constipation), adequate hydration. Protein can sometimes interfere with levodopa absorption - discuss timing with doctor/dietitian.
- Manage stress and ensure adequate sleep.

- Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS): A surgical option for some with advanced PD whose motor symptoms are not adequately controlled by medication or who have disabling dyskinesias. Involves implanting electrodes in specific brain areas.
- Support: Education, counseling, support groups for patients and caregivers.

paronychia.emergency_advice: Seek medical attention if paronychia is severe, shows signs of spreading infection (e.g., red streaks extending up finger/toe, fever, chills), if there's significant pus collection (abscess) needing drainage, if pain is extreme, or if it doesn't improve with home care after a few days. Individuals with diabetes or weakened immune systems should seek care promptly for any signs of infection.
paronychia.general_advice: Paronychia is an infection and inflammation of the skin fold around a fingernail or toenail (the nail fold or paronychium). It can be acute (sudden onset, often painful, usually bacterial - e.g., *Staphylococcus aureus*) or chronic (develops gradually, lasts longer, often due to mixed infection with fungi like Candida and bacteria, or irritant exposure). Acute paronychia often results from minor trauma to the nail fold (e.g., nail biting, hangnails, manicures/pedicures, ingrown nails, finger sucking in children). Chronic paronychia is more common in people whose hands or feet are frequently wet or exposed to irritants/allergens (e.g., dishwashers, bartenders, healthcare workers). Symptoms of acute paronychia include: redness, swelling, pain, and tenderness of the skin around the nail. A pus-filled blister (abscess) may form. Chronic paronychia often presents with swollen, tender, boggy nail folds, sometimes with nail plate changes (ridging, discoloration) and loss of the cuticle.
paronychia.when_to_see_doctor: If symptoms are more than mild, if an abscess is present, or if it's recurrent or chronic, consult a doctor (primary care, dermatologist, or podiatrist for toenails). They can diagnose it, drain any abscess, and prescribe antibiotics (topical or oral) or antifungal medications if needed.
self_care_tips: For mild acute paronychia without significant pus:

- Warm soaks: Soak the affected finger or toe in warm water (with or without Epsom salts or mild antiseptic soap) for 10-15 minutes, 3-4 times a day. This can help reduce pain, inflammation, and may promote drainage if a small amount of pus is present.
- Keep the area clean and dry between soaks.
- Apply an over-the-counter topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a light bandage.
- Avoid trauma to the area (e.g., stop nail biting, picking at hangnails).
For chronic paronychia:
- Identify and avoid irritants or prolonged moisture exposure. Wear gloves for wet work.
- Keep hands/feet dry.
- Apply topical antifungal or mild corticosteroid creams as prescribed by your doctor.
Medical treatment:
- Incision and drainage: If a significant abscess (pus collection) is present, a doctor will need to drain it.
- Antibiotics (oral or topical) for bacterial infection.
- Antifungal medications (topical or oral) for fungal or yeast infection (common in chronic).

Prevention: Avoid biting nails or picking at cuticles. Be careful with manicures/pedicures (ensure sterile instruments). Wear protective gloves for wet work or when handling chemicals. Keep nails neatly trimmed (straight across for toenails). Moisturize hands/cuticles.

paroxysmal_supraventricular_tachycardia.emergency_advice: While PSVT is often not life-threatening in people with healthy hearts, seek immediate medical attention if an episode is prolonged (e.g., >20-30 minutes and not stopping with vagal maneuvers), or if accompanied by severe symptoms like: significant chest pain or pressure, severe shortness of breath, dizziness or lightheadedness leading to fainting (syncope) or near-fainting, or signs of heart failure. If you have underlying heart disease, PSVT can be more serious.
paroxysmal_supraventricular_tachycardia.general_advice: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) is a type of arrhythmia (abnormal heart rhythm) characterized by episodes of a very rapid but regular heartbeat that start and stop abruptly ('paroxysmal'). 'Supraventricular' means the arrhythmia originates above the ventricles (lower heart chambers), typically in the atria or AV node. The heart rate during PSVT is usually between 140 and 250 beats per minute. It's caused by an abnormality in the heart's electrical conduction system, often involving an extra electrical pathway or a re-entrant circuit (where electrical signals travel in a loop). Common types include atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT - most common) and atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT - involves an accessory pathway, e.g., Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome). Symptoms during an episode can include: palpitations (sensation of a rapid, forceful, or fluttering heartbeat), dizziness or lightheadedness, shortness of breath, chest discomfort or tightness, anxiety, and sometimes fatigue or fainting. Episodes can last from a few seconds or minutes to several hours. Triggers can include caffeine, alcohol, stress, fatigue, certain medications, or sometimes occur without a clear trigger.
paroxysmal_supraventricular_tachycardia.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience episodes of a very rapid, regular heartbeat, consult your doctor (primary care or cardiologist/electrophysiologist). Diagnosis often involves an EKG (electrocardiogram - if captured during an episode, it's diagnostic), Holter monitor, event recorder, or sometimes an electrophysiology study (EPS) to identify the specific mechanism of PSVT.
self_care_tips: During an acute PSVT episode, you can try vagal maneuvers (if taught by your doctor and safe for you) to try and stop it:
- Valsalva maneuver: Bear down as if having a bowel movement for 10-15 seconds.

- Carotid sinus massage: Gently massaging the carotid artery in the neck (ONLY if trained by a doctor and no contraindications like carotid artery disease - generally not recommended for self-application).
- Gagging (gently).
- Splashing cold water on the face or immersing face in cold water.
- Coughing.
Medical treatment for acute episodes (if vagal maneuvers fail or in ER):
- Intravenous (IV) medications: Adenosine (very short-acting, often stops PSVT quickly), or sometimes beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.
- Electrical cardioversion (rarely needed for PSVT if unstable or unresponsive to drugs).
Long-term management (if episodes are frequent or very symptomatic):
- Medications (taken daily to prevent episodes): Beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, or antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., flecainide, propafenone).

- Catheter ablation: A procedure where a catheter is guided to the heart, and the abnormal electrical pathway or re-entrant circuit causing the PSVT is identified and ablated (destroyed with radiofrequency energy or cryoablation - freezing). This is often curative and is a common treatment for recurrent, symptomatic PSVT.
Avoid known triggers (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, stimulants) if they provoke your PSVT.

paroxysmal_ventricular_tachycardia.emergency_advice: Ventricular tachycardia is a serious, potentially life-threatening arrhythmia. Seek immediate emergency medical attention (call 911, 999, 112) if you experience symptoms of VT: palpitations (rapid, often forceful heartbeat), dizziness or lightheadedness, shortness of breath, chest pain or pressure, fainting (syncope), or if you feel very unwell. Sustained VT can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation (a chaotic, ineffective quivering of ventricles), which causes sudden cardiac arrest if not treated immediately with defibrillation.
paroxysmal_ventricular_tachycardia.general_advice: Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia (VT or V-tach) is a type of arrhythmia characterized by episodes of a very rapid heartbeat (usually >100-120 beats per minute, often 150-250 bpm) that originate in the ventricles (lower chambers of the heart). 'Paroxysmal' means it starts and stops suddenly. VT can be non-sustained (lasts <30 seconds) or sustained (lasts >30 seconds or causes hemodynamic collapse). It occurs when abnormal electrical signals in the ventricles cause them to beat too quickly and out of sync with the atria. This rapid ventricular rate can prevent the heart from pumping blood effectively to the brain and body. VT is often associated with underlying structural heart disease (e.g., coronary artery disease, previous heart attack/scar tissue, cardiomyopathy, heart failure, valvular heart disease), but can also occur due to electrolyte imbalances (especially low potassium or magnesium), certain medications (proarrhythmic effects), inherited heart rhythm disorders (e.g., long QT syndrome, Brugada syndrome), or rarely in structurally normal hearts (idiopathic VT).
paroxysmal_ventricular_tachycardia.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience symptoms of VT, it's an emergency. If diagnosed, ongoing management by a cardiologist or electrophysiologist is essential. Diagnosis involves an EKG (during an episode is diagnostic), Holter monitor, event recorder, stress test, echocardiogram, cardiac MRI, coronary angiography, or electrophysiology study (EPS) to assess risk and guide treatment.
self_care_tips: Acute treatment of sustained VT (in hospital/emergency setting):
- If hemodynamically unstable (e.g., low blood pressure, loss of consciousness): Immediate synchronized electrical cardioversion (defibrillation if pulseless VT).
- If stable: Intravenous (IV) antiarrhythmic medications (e.g., amiodarone, lidocaine, procainamide).
Long-term management aims to prevent recurrence and sudden cardiac death:
- Treat underlying heart disease (e.g., revascularization for CAD, management of heart failure).
- Medications: Antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., amiodarone, sotalol, mexiletine), beta-blockers.

- Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD): A device implanted in the chest that can detect life-threatening VT or ventricular fibrillation and deliver an electrical shock to restore normal rhythm. Often recommended for those who have survived sustained VT or are at high risk.
- Catheter ablation: A procedure to identify and ablate (destroy) the abnormal electrical focus or circuit in the ventricle causing the VT. Can be effective for some types of VT.
- Lifestyle: Avoid known triggers (e.g., stimulants, electrolyte imbalances - maintain as per doctor's advice), manage stress, adhere to medication regimen.
Follow your cardiologist's comprehensive treatment plan strictly.

pelvic_fistula.emergency_advice: While not usually an acute life-threatening emergency itself, seek urgent medical attention if a pelvic fistula leads to: signs of severe infection (e.g., spreading cellulitis, abscess, sepsis - fever, chills, rapid heart rate, confusion); severe, uncontrolled leakage causing significant skin breakdown or dehydration; or if it's a complication of recent surgery or trauma causing acute, severe symptoms.
pelvic_fistula.general_advice: A pelvic fistula is an abnormal opening or tunnel that connects two or more organs or spaces within the pelvis, or connects a pelvic organ to the skin. Common types in women include: 1) Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF): Between the bladder and vagina, causing continuous leakage of urine into the vagina. 2) Rectovaginal fistula (RVF): Between the rectum and vagina, causing leakage of stool or gas from the vagina. 3) Ureterovaginal fistula: Between a ureter (tube from kidney to bladder) and vagina, causing urine leakage. 4) Enterovaginal fistula: Between intestine and vagina. 5) Vesicouterine fistula: Between bladder and uterus. Causes of pelvic fistulas include: childbirth trauma (prolonged or obstructed labor - a major cause in developing countries, often leading to obstetric fistula), pelvic surgery (e.g., hysterectomy, C-section, rectal surgery), radiation therapy to the pelvis (for cancer), inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease), diverticulitis, cancer (e.g., cervical, rectal, bladder cancer invading adjacent organs), or trauma. Symptoms depend on the type and location of fistula but often involve abnormal leakage of urine, stool, or gas from the vagina or skin, recurrent urinary tract infections, vaginal irritation or infections, and sometimes pain or foul odor. Fistulas can cause significant physical discomfort and psychosocial distress.
pelvic_fistula.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience abnormal leakage of urine or stool from the vagina, or other symptoms suggestive of a pelvic fistula, consult your doctor (gynecologist, urologist, or colorectal surgeon). Diagnosis involves a pelvic exam, and may include tests like dye tests (e.g., instilling dye into bladder or rectum to see if it leaks into vagina), cystoscopy, sigmoidoscopy/colonoscopy, fistulogram (X-ray with contrast to outline fistula tract), CT scan, or MRI.
self_care_tips: Pelvic fistulas usually require surgical repair. Conservative management (e.g., for very small fistulas or if surgery is not an option) may involve managing symptoms.

- Surgical repair: The type of surgery depends on the fistula's location, size, and cause. It aims to close the abnormal opening and repair damaged tissues. Multiple surgeries may sometimes be needed. Success rates vary.
- If an underlying condition like Crohn's disease is present, treating that condition is crucial.
- For vesicovaginal fistula, a urinary catheter may be used temporarily before or after surgery to divert urine and allow healing.
- For rectovaginal fistula, a temporary colostomy may sometimes be needed to divert stool and allow the fistula to heal after repair.
Hygiene and skin care:
- Keep the perineal area clean and dry to prevent skin irritation and infection from leakage. Use gentle cleansers and pat dry.
- Barrier creams (e.g., zinc oxide) can help protect the skin.
- Absorbent pads or incontinence products may be needed.
Dietary modifications: For rectovaginal fistula, a low-residue diet or bulking agents may sometimes be suggested to manage stool consistency (discuss with doctor/dietitian).
Pelvic floor muscle exercises: May be helpful in some cases, especially after surgical repair.
Emotional support: Fistulas can be very distressing. Counseling or support groups can be beneficial.

pelvic_inflammatory_disease.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention if you have symptoms of PID and develop: severe lower abdominal pain, high fever (e.g., >101°F or 38.3°C), persistent nausea and vomiting (unable to keep anything down), signs of sepsis (confusion, rapid heart rate, low blood pressure, extreme illness), or if you suspect a tubo-ovarian abscess (a collection of pus in ovary/tube - can cause severe pain and rupture). PID can be a serious infection requiring prompt treatment to prevent long-term complications.
pelvic_inflammatory_disease.general_advice: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an infection and inflammation of the female upper genital tract, including the uterus (endometritis), fallopian tubes (salpingitis), ovaries (oophoritis), and sometimes surrounding pelvic structures (pelvic peritonitis). It's usually caused by bacteria ascending from the vagina and cervix, most commonly from sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like chlamydia and gonorrhea. However, other bacteria normally found in the vagina can also cause PID, especially after procedures that disrupt the cervical barrier (e.g., IUD insertion, childbirth, miscarriage, abortion). Symptoms can range from mild or absent to severe. Common symptoms include: lower abdominal or pelvic pain (can be dull, cramping, or sharp), abnormal vaginal discharge (often with a foul odor, may be yellowish or greenish), abnormal uterine bleeding (e.g., bleeding between periods, after intercourse, heavier periods), pain or bleeding during intercourse (dyspareunia), fever and chills, and painful or frequent urination. Untreated or inadequately treated PID can lead to serious long-term complications, including chronic pelvic pain, infertility (due to scarring/blockage of fallopian tubes), ectopic pregnancy, and tubo-ovarian abscess.
pelvic_inflammatory_disease.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience any symptoms of PID, consult your doctor or gynecologist immediately. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications. Diagnosis is often based on clinical findings (pelvic exam showing cervical motion tenderness, uterine tenderness, or adnexal tenderness), and may be supported by tests for STIs (chlamydia, gonorrhea), white blood cell count, inflammatory markers (ESR/CRP), ultrasound (to look for tubo-ovarian abscess or other pelvic pathology), or rarely, laparoscopy.
self_care_tips: PID requires treatment with antibiotics (usually a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover likely pathogens, including chlamydia and gonorrhea). This may involve oral antibiotics, or sometimes hospitalization for intravenous (IV) antibiotics if infection is severe, if pregnant, if tubo-ovarian abscess is suspected, or if unable to tolerate oral medication.
- Take all prescribed antibiotics exactly as directed for the full course, even if symptoms improve.
- Rest and avoid strenuous activity during acute illness.
- Pain relievers (NSAIDs, acetaminophen) for pain and fever.

- Avoid sexual intercourse until treatment is completed, symptoms have resolved, and your doctor says it's okay. Your sexual partner(s) from the past 60 days should also be evaluated and treated for STIs to prevent reinfection and further spread, even if they have no symptoms.
- Attend follow-up appointment(s) with your doctor to ensure the infection has cleared.
Prevention:
- Practice safe sex (condoms) to reduce STI risk.
- Get regular STI screening if sexually active and at risk.
- Seek prompt treatment for any STIs.
- Avoid douching, as it can disrupt normal vaginal flora and potentially push bacteria up into the upper genital tract.

pelvic_organ_prolapse.emergency_advice: While not usually a life-threatening emergency, seek urgent medical attention if pelvic organ prolapse leads to: acute urinary retention (sudden inability to urinate); severe pain; or signs of ulceration, bleeding, or infection of the prolapsed tissue. Also, if a prolapsed organ becomes incarcerated (trapped and cannot be pushed back in) and causes severe symptoms.
pelvic_organ_prolapse.general_advice: Pelvic organ prolapse (POP) is a condition where one or more of the pelvic organs (bladder, uterus, vagina, small bowel, or rectum) drop (prolapse) from their normal position and bulge or protrude into or out of the vagina. This occurs when the muscles and connective tissues of the pelvic floor, which support these organs, become weakened or damaged. Common types include: 1) Cystocele (prolapsed bladder, 'anterior prolapse'): Bladder bulges into front wall of vagina. 2) Rectocele (prolapsed rectum, 'posterior prolapse'): Rectum bulges into back wall of vagina. 3) Uterine prolapse: Uterus drops down into vagina. 4) Vaginal vault prolapse: Top of vagina drops down after hysterectomy. 5) Enterocele: Small intestine bulges into top part of vagina. Risk factors include: childbirth (especially multiple vaginal deliveries, large babies, forceps/vacuum delivery), aging and menopause (due to estrogen loss affecting tissue strength), obesity, chronic constipation or straining, chronic cough (e.g., from smoking or lung disease), heavy lifting, previous pelvic surgery (e.g., hysterectomy), and genetic factors affecting connective tissue. Symptoms can vary depending on the type and severity of prolapse but may include: a feeling of pressure, fullness, heaviness, or bulging in the vagina or pelvis (may feel like 'something is falling out'); a visible bulge or protrusion from the vagina; urinary problems (e.g., stress incontinence - leaking with cough/sneeze, urge incontinence, incomplete bladder emptying, recurrent UTIs); bowel problems (e.g., constipation, difficulty evacuating stool - may need to splint/press on vagina to have BM, fecal incontinence); pain or discomfort during intercourse (dyspareunia); and low back pain. Symptoms often worsen with prolonged standing or at end of day.
pelvic_organ_prolapse.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse, consult your doctor (gynecologist, urogyn.ecologist, or urologist). Diagnosis is made by pelvic exam, often while bearing down or standing. Severity is graded. Treatment depends on symptoms and impact on quality of life.
self_care_tips: Management options depend on type, severity, symptoms, and patient preference.
- Lifestyle modifications:

- Pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises): Can strengthen pelvic floor muscles and may help mild prolapse or prevent worsening. Best learned with guidance from a physical therapist specializing in pelvic floor.
- Maintain a healthy weight.
- Avoid constipation and straining: High-fiber diet, adequate fluids, stool softeners if needed.
- Avoid heavy lifting and activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure.
- Treat chronic cough.

- Vaginal pessary: A removable device (various shapes/sizes) inserted into the vagina to support the prolapsed organs. Needs to be fitted by a healthcare provider and requires regular cleaning and check-ups.

- Surgical repair: Various surgical procedures can be done to repair weakened tissues and restore organs to their normal position (e.g., anterior/posterior repair, sacrocolpopexy, sacrospinous fixation, colpocleisis - vaginal closure for women not sexually active). Surgery may involve using native tissue or synthetic mesh (use of mesh has become more controversial for some procedures due to complications). Hysterectomy may be part of some prolapse repairs if uterine prolapse is present.
If asymptomatic or mild, no specific treatment may be needed other than observation and lifestyle measures.

pemphigus.emergency_advice: Pemphigus can be a life-threatening autoimmune blistering disease if not treated appropriately, especially if widespread or with severe mucosal involvement leading to dehydration, malnutrition, or secondary infections. Seek urgent medical attention for: rapidly spreading blisters or erosions, extensive skin loss, severe pain, difficulty eating or drinking due to painful mouth/throat sores, signs of severe infection (fever, chills, pus, sepsis), or significant dehydration.
pemphigus.general_advice: Pemphigus is a group of rare, chronic autoimmune blistering diseases that affect the skin and mucous membranes (e.g., mouth, throat, nose, eyes, genitals). In pemphigus, the immune system produces autoantibodies that attack desmogleins, which are proteins responsible for cell-to-cell adhesion in the epidermis (outer layer of skin) and mucous membranes. This causes skin cells to separate from each other (acantholysis), leading to the formation of fragile, flaccid (soft, easily ruptured) blisters and erosions (raw, open sores). The two main types are: 1) Pemphigus vulgaris (PV - most common and often most severe): Typically starts with painful blisters and erosions in the mouth, which can precede skin lesions by weeks or months. Skin blisters are usually soft, easily ruptured (leaving painful erosions), and can occur anywhere on the body. Nikolsky's sign (gentle rubbing of normal-appearing skin causes blistering or separation of epidermis) is often positive. 2) Pemphigus foliaceus (PF): Milder form, usually affects only the skin (rarely mucous membranes). Blisters are more superficial, crusted, and scaly, often on scalp, face, chest, and back. Itching can be prominent. Other rarer forms exist (e.g., paraneoplastic pemphigus - associated with cancer; IgA pemphigus). Pemphigus is not contagious.
pemphigus.when_to_see_doctor: If you develop persistent blisters or sores on your skin or in your mouth/other mucous membranes, consult a doctor or dermatologist immediately. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to control the disease, promote healing, and prevent complications. Diagnosis involves a skin biopsy (for histology and direct immunofluorescence - DIF, to detect autoantibodies in skin) and blood tests (for circulating autoantibodies - indirect immunofluorescence - IIF, or ELISA for anti-desmoglein antibodies).
self_care_tips: Pemphigus requires long-term medical management by a dermatologist, often with a multidisciplinary team.

- Corticosteroids (systemic, e.g., oral prednisone): Mainstay of initial treatment to rapidly suppress the autoimmune response and control blistering. High doses are often needed initially, then tapered slowly.

- Immunosuppressants (steroid-sparing agents, e.g., azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclophosphamide, methotrexate): Used in combination with or after corticosteroids to allow steroid dose reduction and for long-term maintenance.
- Rituximab (a monoclonal antibody targeting B-cells): Increasingly used as a first-line or second-line therapy, can induce long-term remission.
- Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasma exchange: May be used for severe, refractory disease.
- Topical treatments: Corticosteroid creams/ointments for skin lesions, anesthetic/protective mouthwashes for oral lesions.
Wound care for skin erosions is critical:
- Gentle cleansing.
- Non-adherent dressings to protect raw areas and promote healing.
- Prevent secondary infection.
Oral care for mouth lesions:
- Meticulous but gentle oral hygiene.
- Eat soft, bland, non-irritating foods if mouth is sore. Avoid spicy, acidic, crunchy foods.
- Maintain good nutrition and hydration.
Pain management.
Protect skin from trauma.
Monitor for medication side effects and signs of infection (due to immunosuppression).
Psychological support, as pemphigus can be very distressing.

pericarditis.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention if pericarditis symptoms are accompanied by: signs of cardiac tamponade (a life-threatening complication where fluid buildup around heart compresses it) - severe shortness of breath, chest pain, rapid heartbeat, low blood pressure, dizziness, fainting, distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds; or if chest pain is very severe and crushing (to rule out heart attack).
pericarditis.general_advice: Pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium, the thin, sac-like membrane that surrounds the heart. The pericardium normally contains a small amount of lubricating fluid. When it becomes inflamed, it can cause chest pain and sometimes lead to fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac (pericardial effusion). Causes of pericarditis can be: 1) Idiopathic (unknown cause - most common). 2) Viral infections (e.g., coxsackievirus, echovirus, influenza, HIV - common infectious cause). 3) Bacterial or fungal infections (less common, more serious). 4) Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma). 5) Post-myocardial infarction (heart attack) - Dressler's syndrome. 6) Post-cardiac surgery. 7) Kidney failure (uremic pericarditis). 8) Trauma to chest or heart. 9) Cancer (e.g., metastatic, or primary pericardial tumors - rare). 10) Certain medications. The hallmark symptom is sharp, stabbing chest pain, often located in the center or left side of the chest, which may radiate to the shoulder, neck, or arm. The pain is typically worse when lying down, taking a deep breath, or coughing, and may be relieved by sitting up and leaning forward. Other symptoms can include fever, fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, dry cough, and palpitations. A characteristic 'pericardial friction rub' (a grating or scratchy sound) may be heard with a stethoscope.
pericarditis.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience sudden, sharp chest pain, especially with the characteristics described, consult your doctor or go to an emergency department to rule out other serious causes of chest pain (like heart attack or pulmonary embolism) and to diagnose pericarditis. Diagnosis involves a physical exam (listening for friction rub), EKG (electrocardiogram - often shows characteristic changes), echocardiogram (to look for pericardial effusion and assess heart function), chest X-ray, and blood tests (for inflammation markers like CRP/ESR, cardiac enzymes to rule out heart attack, and tests for underlying causes).
self_care_tips: Treatment depends on the cause and severity.
- For uncomplicated viral or idiopathic pericarditis:
- Rest.
- Pain relievers and anti-inflammatory drugs: NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen, indomethacin) are a mainstay. Colchicine is often added to NSAIDs to reduce inflammation and risk of recurrence.

- Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) may be used if NSAIDs/colchicine are ineffective or contraindicated, or for specific causes (e.g., autoimmune), but are generally reserved due to higher recurrence risk if tapered too quickly.
- If bacterial infection: Antibiotics.
- If due to underlying systemic disease: Treatment of that condition.
Avoid strenuous physical activity until inflammation resolves and cleared by doctor, as it can worsen pericarditis or lead to recurrence.
If a significant pericardial effusion develops causing symptoms or cardiac tamponade, pericardiocentesis (draining fluid with a needle) or surgical drainage (pericardial window) may be needed.
Follow up with your doctor to monitor recovery and for signs of recurrence or complications like constrictive pericarditis (rare, chronic scarring of pericardium).

peripheral_arterial_disease.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for: signs of acute limb ischemia (sudden blockage of blood flow to a limb) - the '6 P's': Pain (severe, sudden), Pallor (paleness), Pulselessness (absent pulse distal to blockage), Paresthesia (numbness/tingling), Paralysis (weakness/inability to move), Poikilothermia (coldness of limb). This is a vascular emergency requiring urgent intervention to save the limb. Also, non-healing ulcers or gangrene (tissue death, often black discoloration) in the feet/legs of someone with PAD need urgent care.
peripheral_arterial_disease.general_advice: Peripheral artery disease (PAD), also known as peripheral vascular disease (PVD) when referring specifically to arteries, is a common circulatory problem in which narrowed or blocked arteries reduce blood flow to the limbs, most commonly the legs and feet. It's usually caused by atherosclerosis (buildup of fatty plaques in arteries), the same process that causes coronary artery disease and carotid artery disease. Reduced blood flow can lead to various symptoms, especially during physical activity when muscles need more oxygen. The most common symptom is intermittent claudication: cramping pain or aching in the leg muscles (calves, thighs, or buttocks) that is triggered by exercise (like walking) and relieved by a few minutes of rest. Other symptoms can include: leg numbness or weakness, coldness in the lower leg or foot (especially compared to other side), sores or ulcers on toes, feet, or legs that heal slowly or not at all, changes in skin color of legs/feet (pale, bluish, or shiny), hair loss or slow hair growth on legs/feet, slow toenail growth, diminished or absent pulses in legs/feet, and in severe cases, rest pain (pain in feet/toes even when not walking, often worse at night when legs are elevated, relieved by dangling legs over side of bed) or critical limb ischemia (CLI - rest pain, ulcers, or gangrene, high risk of amputation). Risk factors are similar to those for atherosclerosis: smoking (major risk factor), diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, older age, obesity, physical inactivity, and family history.
peripheral_arterial_disease.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience leg pain with walking, non-healing sores on your feet/legs, or other symptoms of PAD, consult your doctor (primary care, vascular specialist, or cardiologist). Diagnosis involves a physical exam (checking pulses, skin), ankle-brachial index (ABI - compares blood pressure in ankle to arm), Doppler ultrasound, angiography (CT, MR, or catheter-based).
self_care_tips: Management aims to relieve symptoms, improve walking ability, prevent progression of atherosclerosis, and reduce risk of heart attack/stroke (as PAD is a marker for widespread atherosclerosis).
- Lifestyle modifications (crucial):
- Smoking cessation is the single most important step.
- Regular exercise: Supervised exercise programs (walking programs) are very effective for improving claudication. Walk until pain occurs, rest, then walk again.
- Heart-healthy diet (low in saturated/trans fats, cholesterol, sodium).
- Maintain a healthy weight.
- Meticulous foot care, especially if diabetic or have neuropathy: Inspect feet daily, wear proper footwear, avoid injury, prompt treatment of any sores.
- Medications:
- Antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) to reduce risk of blood clots.
- Statins (to lower cholesterol and stabilize plaques).
- Blood pressure medications (to control hypertension).
- Diabetes medications (to control blood sugar).
- Medications for claudication (e.g., cilostazol - can improve walking distance).
- Procedures/Surgery (for severe PAD, critical limb ischemia, or disabling claudication unresponsive to conservative treatment):
- Angioplasty and stenting: To open narrowed/blocked arteries.
- Bypass surgery: To reroute blood flow around a blockage using a graft.
- Atherectomy: To remove plaque from an artery.
Attend all regular follow-up appointments with your doctor/vascular specialist.
