- Surgery: Mainstay of treatment for localized stomach cancer, aiming to remove the tumor and nearby lymph nodes. May involve partial gastrectomy (removal of part of stomach) or total gastrectomy (removal of entire stomach).

- Chemotherapy: May be used before surgery (neoadjuvant) to shrink tumor, after surgery (adjuvant) to kill remaining cancer cells, or as primary treatment for advanced/metastatic disease. Often combination regimens.
- Radiation therapy: May be used with chemotherapy (chemoradiation), often before or after surgery, or for palliative symptom relief.
- Targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for HER2-positive cancers, ramucirumab) or Immunotherapy (e.g., checkpoint inhibitors for some advanced cancers) are options for certain types/stages.
- Palliative care and symptom management are crucial: Pain control, management of nausea/vomiting, nutritional support (dietitian consultation, sometimes feeding tubes if difficulty eating).
Lifestyle factors that may reduce risk or support health during treatment:
- Eradication of H. pylori infection if present.
- Healthy diet rich in fruits/vegetables, limit salty/smoked/pickled foods.
- Quit smoking.
- Maintain a healthy weight.
Follow your comprehensive treatment plan and attend all follow-up appointments for surveillance.
Seek emotional and psychological support.

strep_throat.emergency_advice: While strep throat itself is usually not an emergency if treated, seek immediate medical attention if a sore throat is accompanied by: severe difficulty breathing or swallowing, drooling, inability to open mouth fully, stiff neck, or a rapidly worsening rash with high fever (could be severe scarlet fever or other serious condition like toxic shock syndrome - rare). Also, if complications like peritonsillar abscess (see separate entry) or rheumatic fever (see separate entry) are suspected.
strep_throat.general_advice: Strep throat, or streptococcal pharyngitis, is a bacterial infection of the throat and tonsils caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS) bacteria (*Streptococcus pyogenes*). It's common, especially in children and adolescents (ages 5-15), and is contagious, spreading through respiratory droplets (coughing, sneezing) or direct contact. Symptoms typically include: sudden onset of severe sore throat, pain when swallowing (odynophagia), fever (often 101°F/38.3°C or higher), red and swollen tonsils (often with white patches or streaks of pus - exudate), tiny red spots (petechiae) on the soft or hard palate (roof of mouth), and swollen, tender lymph nodes in the neck. Headache, stomach ache, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes a rash (scarlet fever - see separate entry) can also occur. Cough and runny nose are usually NOT prominent features of strep throat (more typical of viral sore throats). Prompt diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics are important to relieve symptoms, prevent spread, and reduce the risk of rare but serious complications like acute rheumatic fever (which can damage heart valves) and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (kidney inflammation).
strep_throat.when_to_see_doctor: If you or your child has a sore throat with fever, especially if accompanied by other symptoms of strep throat (red/swollen tonsils with pus, swollen neck glands, no cough/runny nose), consult your doctor. Diagnosis is made with a rapid strep test (results in minutes) and/or a throat culture (takes 1-2 days for results - more accurate) from a throat swab.
self_care_tips: If strep throat is diagnosed, antibiotics (usually penicillin or amoxicillin, or alternatives if allergic) will be prescribed for 10 days. It is crucial to take the full course of antibiotics as directed, even if symptoms improve quickly, to completely eradicate the bacteria and prevent complications.
Symptomatic relief:
- Rest.
- Drink plenty of fluids (water, warm tea with honey, broth) to soothe throat and stay hydrated.
- Pain and fever relief: Acetaminophen (Tylenol) or NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen).
- Sore throat relief: Gargle with warm salt water. Suck on throat lozenges or hard candy (avoid in young children). Eat soft foods.
- Use a cool-mist humidifier.
Prevention of spread:
- Stay home from school/work until fever is gone and on antibiotics for at least 12-24 hours (or as advised by doctor).
- Wash hands frequently.
- Cover coughs/sneezes.
- Do not share utensils, cups, food, or towels.
- Wash dishes and utensils used by infected person in hot, soapy water or dishwasher.
- Replace toothbrush after illness resolves (or a few days into antibiotic treatment).

stress_incontinence.general_advice: Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) is the involuntary leakage of small amounts of urine that occurs during activities that increase abdominal pressure and put stress on the bladder. Common triggers include coughing, sneezing, laughing, lifting heavy objects, running, jumping, or exercising. It happens when the muscles and tissues supporting the bladder and urethra (pelvic floor muscles) and/or the urethral sphincter (muscle that controls urine flow) are weakened or damaged, preventing the urethra from closing completely when pressure is applied. SUI is very common, especially in women. Risk factors include: pregnancy and childbirth (vaginal delivery can stretch/damage pelvic floor), menopause (due to estrogen loss affecting tissue tone), obesity, chronic cough (e.g., from smoking or lung disease), chronic constipation or straining, previous pelvic surgery (e.g., hysterectomy, prostate surgery in men - though urge incontinence is more common after prostatectomy), high-impact sports, and genetic factors affecting connective tissue. SUI is different from urge incontinence (sudden, intense urge to urinate followed by leakage, often from overactive bladder) or overflow incontinence (leakage from an overly full bladder - see separate entries), though mixed incontinence (combination of stress and urge) is also common.
stress_incontinence.when_to_see_doctor: If stress incontinence is bothersome, frequent, or impacting your quality of life, consult your doctor (primary care, gynecologist, urologist, or urogyn.ecologist). They can diagnose SUI based on symptoms and a physical exam (including pelvic exam, cough stress test), and rule out other causes of incontinence or contributing factors (like UTI). Urodynamic testing may be done in some cases.
self_care_tips: Management depends on severity and patient preference.
- Lifestyle modifications:

- Pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises): Strengthening these muscles can significantly improve or resolve SUI. It's important to do them correctly and consistently. A physical therapist specializing in pelvic floor can provide guidance.
- Weight loss if overweight or obese (reduces pressure on bladder).
- Manage chronic cough or constipation.
- Fluid management: Drink adequate fluids, but avoid excessive intake. Limit bladder irritants (caffeine, alcohol) if they also cause urgency.
- Timed voiding or bladder training (more for urge incontinence, but can be part of overall bladder health).
- Devices:
- Vaginal pessaries (for women): Removable devices inserted into vagina to support bladder neck/urethra.
- Incontinence pads or absorbent products for managing leakage.
- Medical treatments (less common or effective for pure SUI than for urge incontinence, but sometimes used):
- Estrogen therapy (topical vaginal estrogen for postmenopausal women can improve tissue health but may not fully resolve SUI).
- Duloxetine (an antidepressant) has shown some benefit for SUI in some women but is not FDA-approved for this in US and has side effects.
- Surgical procedures (often very effective for SUI):
- Sling procedures (mid-urethral slings - TVT, TOT): Most common surgery. A small strip of synthetic mesh or biological material is placed under the urethra to provide support.
- Bladder neck suspension (e.g., Burch colposuspension).
- Bulking agent injections around urethra.
Avoid activities that you know trigger leakage, or use a pad during them. Urinate before strenuous activity.

stricture_of_the_esophagus.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention if an esophageal stricture causes: complete inability to swallow food or liquids (food impaction or complete obstruction); severe chest pain; persistent vomiting (especially if bloody); or significant, unintentional weight loss due to difficulty eating.
stricture_of_the_esophagus.general_advice: An esophageal stricture is an abnormal narrowing of the esophagus, the muscular tube that carries food from the throat to the stomach. This narrowing can make it difficult for food and sometimes liquids to pass through, leading to dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). Benign (non-cancerous) esophageal strictures are most commonly caused by scarring and fibrosis resulting from chronic inflammation or injury to the esophageal lining. Common causes include: 1) Chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): Repeated exposure to stomach acid damages the esophagus, leading to inflammation (reflux esophagitis) and subsequent scarring/narrowing. This is the most frequent cause. 2) Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE): An allergic inflammatory condition that can cause strictures. 3) Ingestion of caustic substances (e.g., strong acids or alkalis - accidental or intentional). 4) Radiation therapy to the chest or neck (for cancer). 5) Complications of esophageal surgery or procedures (e.g., after endoscopic resection of lesions). 6) Prolonged use of a nasogastric (NG) tube. 7) Rare skin diseases affecting esophagus (e.g., pemphigoid). Symptoms primarily include: dysphagia (often starting with solids, then progressing to liquids if severe), a sensation of food getting stuck in the chest, pain when swallowing (odynophagia), regurgitation of undigested food, heartburn, frequent coughing or choking when eating, and sometimes weight loss or nutritional deficiencies due to reduced food intake.
stricture_of_the_esophagus.when_to_see_doctor: If you have difficulty swallowing or other symptoms suggestive of an esophageal stricture, consult your doctor (primary care or gastroenterologist). Diagnosis involves an upper GI endoscopy (to visualize the esophagus, assess the stricture, and take biopsies to rule out cancer or identify cause like EoE) and/or a barium swallow X-ray (esophagram - can show narrowing and its extent).
self_care_tips: Management depends on the cause and severity of the stricture.

- Esophageal dilation (dilatation): The primary treatment. During endoscopy, a dilating instrument (e.g., balloon dilator or bougies - progressively larger weighted tubes) is passed through the stricture to stretch and widen it. Multiple sessions may be needed. Dilation provides symptom relief but strictures can recur.
- Treat the underlying cause:
- For GERD-related strictures: Aggressive acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is crucial to prevent recurrence after dilation.
- For EoE-related strictures: Dietary elimination, topical swallowed corticosteroids, or biologic therapies, often with dilation.
- Corticosteroid injections into the stricture site during endoscopy may sometimes be used to reduce inflammation and recurrence after dilation.
- Esophageal stenting: A mesh tube (stent) may be placed across a refractory stricture to keep it open, but this is usually temporary or for palliative care if stricture is malignant.
- Surgery to resect the strictured segment is rarely needed for benign strictures unless other methods fail.
Dietary modifications during symptomatic periods:
- Eat small, frequent meals.
- Chew food thoroughly and eat slowly.
- Choose soft, moist foods. Avoid dry, tough, or bulky foods that are hard to swallow.
- Sit upright when eating and for a while afterwards.
- Drink fluids with meals to help food pass.
If GERD is the cause, follow GERD lifestyle recommendations (see GERD entry).

stroke.emergency_advice: Stroke is a medical emergency. Call emergency services (911, 999, 112) immediately if you or someone else experiences sudden signs of stroke. Use the FAST acronym: F - Face drooping (ask person to smile, does one side droop?), A - Arm weakness (ask to raise both arms, does one drift downward?), S - Speech difficulty (slurred speech, unable to speak, or hard to understand - ask to repeat a simple sentence), T - Time to call emergency services. Other sudden symptoms can include: numbness or weakness of face, arm, or leg (especially on one side); confusion, trouble understanding speech; vision problems in one or both eyes (blurred, double, or loss of vision); dizziness, loss of balance, or coordination problems; or severe headache with no known cause. Time is critical; prompt treatment can minimize brain damage and improve outcomes.
stroke.general_advice: A stroke, or cerebrovascular accident (CVA), occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or severely reduced, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients, which causes brain cells to die within minutes. There are two main types of stroke: 1) Ischemic stroke (most common, about 85%): Caused by a blockage (occlusion) of an artery supplying blood to the brain. The blockage is usually due to a blood clot (thrombus) forming on an atherosclerotic plaque within a brain artery (thrombotic stroke), or an embolus (clot or debris) traveling from elsewhere in the body (e.g., heart - common with atrial fibrillation, or carotid arteries) and lodging in a brain artery (embolic stroke). 2) Hemorrhagic stroke: Caused by bleeding in or around the brain when a blood vessel ruptures. Includes intracerebral hemorrhage (bleeding within brain tissue - see separate entry) and subarachnoid hemorrhage (bleeding in space around brain, often from ruptured aneurysm - see separate entry). A Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA or 'mini-stroke') is a temporary episode of stroke-like symptoms caused by a brief interruption of blood flow to the brain, usually lasting less than an hour and causing no permanent damage. However, TIAs are a major warning sign of future stroke risk and require urgent medical evaluation.
stroke.when_to_see_doctor: Immediate emergency medical care in a hospital with stroke capabilities (stroke center) is essential for any suspected stroke or TIA.
self_care_tips: Self-care is NOT for managing an acute stroke. Emergency treatment depends on type of stroke:

- For ischemic stroke: If eligible (e.g., within 3-4.5 hour window from symptom onset, no contraindications), thrombolytic therapy ('clot-busting' drug like alteplase - tPA) may be given intravenously to dissolve the clot. Mechanical thrombectomy (catheter-based procedure to remove clot) is an option for large artery occlusions, can be done up to 24 hours in select patients. Antiplatelet drugs (aspirin) are usually started.
- For hemorrhagic stroke: Focus is on controlling bleeding, reducing blood pressure, managing intracranial pressure. Surgery may be needed to stop bleeding, remove hematoma, or repair aneurysm/AVM.

Post-stroke rehabilitation is crucial and often involves a multidisciplinary team (physiatrist, physical/occupational/speech therapists, psychologist, social worker) to help regain lost function, adapt to disabilities, and prevent recurrence. Can include: mobility training, speech therapy, cognitive rehabilitation, management of depression/anxiety.
Long-term prevention of recurrent stroke (secondary prevention):
- Manage risk factors: Control high blood pressure (most important), high cholesterol, diabetes, atrial fibrillation (often requires anticoagulants).
- Lifestyle changes: Heart-healthy diet, regular physical activity (as able), smoking cessation, limit alcohol, healthy weight.
- Medications: Antiplatelet drugs (aspirin, clopidogrel), anticoagulants (if AFib or other indication), statins, blood pressure medications.
- Carotid endarterectomy or stenting: If significant carotid artery stenosis is a cause.
- Follow up regularly with your neurologist and primary care doctor.

stye.emergency_advice: While usually not an emergency, seek medical attention if a stye is very large, extremely painful, doesn't improve or worsens after a few days of home care, significantly affects vision, or if there are signs of spreading infection (e.g., redness/swelling spreading across eyelid or to cheek, fever - could be preseptal cellulitis). Also, if styes are recurrent.
stye.general_advice: A stye, also known as a hordeolum, is an acute, localized infection or inflammation of one or more of the small glands in the eyelid. It typically appears as a red, tender, painful, pimple-like bump at or near the edge of the eyelid. There are two types: 1) External hordeolum: An infection of an eyelash follicle or a gland of Zeis or Moll (sweat/oil glands associated with eyelash follicles). Appears as a small pustule at the eyelid margin, pointing outwards. 2) Internal hordeolum: An infection of a Meibomian gland (oil glands within the tarsal plate of the eyelid). Usually larger, more painful, and points inwards towards the conjunctiva, or can cause more diffuse eyelid swelling. Styes are most commonly caused by *Staphylococcus aureus* (staph) bacteria. They are not usually contagious in the same way as conjunctivitis, but bacteria can be spread if hygiene is poor. Sometimes an internal hordeolum can evolve into a chalazion (a chronic, non-tender lump - see separate entry) if the gland remains blocked after infection resolves.
stye.when_to_see_doctor: Most styes resolve on their own or with home care within a week or two. However, see a doctor or eye doctor if it's very painful, large, not improving, affecting vision, or if you have recurrent styes. A doctor can confirm the diagnosis and may prescribe topical antibiotic ointment or, rarely, oral antibiotics if there's associated cellulitis. If a stye is very large or points (forms a head), a doctor may make a small incision to drain it (do not attempt this yourself).
self_care_tips: Apply warm compresses to the affected eyelid for 10-15 minutes, 3-4 times a day. The warmth can help relieve pain, reduce swelling, and promote drainage if a head has formed.
Keep the eyelid clean. Gently wash the eyelids with mild soap and water or a gentle eyelid cleanser.
Avoid squeezing or trying to pop the stye, as this can spread infection or cause scarring.
Do not wear eye makeup or contact lenses while you have a stye.
Wash hands frequently and avoid touching your eyes.
If prescribed topical antibiotic ointment, apply a small amount to the affected area as directed.
Once the stye drains, keep the area clean.
If styes are recurrent, your doctor may investigate for underlying conditions like blepharitis (eyelid inflammation) or rosacea, and may recommend regular eyelid hygiene practices.

subacute_thyroiditis.display_name: Subacute Thyroiditis (De Quervain's Thyroiditis, Granulomatous Thyroiditis)
subacute_thyroiditis.emergency_advice: While usually self-limiting, seek medical attention if neck pain is extremely severe and uncontrolled, if there are symptoms of severe hyperthyroidism (e.g., very rapid heart rate, high fever, agitation - though frank thyroid storm is rare with subacute thyroiditis), or if there are compressive symptoms from a very large, tender thyroid (e.g., difficulty breathing or swallowing - rare).
subacute_thyroiditis.general_advice: Subacute thyroiditis, also known as de Quervain's thyroiditis or granulomatous thyroiditis, is an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland, thought to be caused by a viral infection or a post-viral inflammatory response. It often follows an upper respiratory tract infection. The inflammation causes thyroid cells to be damaged and release stored thyroid hormones into the bloodstream, leading to a temporary period of hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid). This is then often followed by a transient period of hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) as the gland recovers, and finally, a return to normal thyroid function (euthyroidism) in most individuals (usually within 12-18 months). The hallmark symptom is neck pain and tenderness, often localized over the thyroid gland (at base of neck), which can be severe and may radiate to the jaw or ears. The thyroid gland is often enlarged and tender to palpation. Other symptoms during the hyperthyroid phase can include: fever, fatigue, malaise, nervousness, anxiety, palpitations, heat intolerance, sweating, weight loss, and tremor. During the hypothyroid phase, symptoms can include fatigue, cold intolerance, constipation, weight gain, and dry skin. Some people may experience only one phase or cycle through them.
subacute_thyroiditis.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience neck pain with tenderness over the thyroid, especially if accompanied by fever or symptoms of hyper- or hypothyroidism, consult your doctor (primary care or endocrinologist). Diagnosis is based on clinical symptoms, physical exam (tender, enlarged thyroid), and blood tests: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are usually very high (indicating inflammation). Thyroid function tests typically show low TSH and high free T4/T3 during hyperthyroid phase, then high TSH and low free T4/T3 during hypothyroid phase. Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) test shows very low uptake during hyperthyroid phase (as thyroid is inflamed and not actively producing new hormone, just leaking stored hormone). Thyroid ultrasound may show characteristic features.
self_care_tips: Subacute thyroiditis is usually self-limiting, and treatment is primarily symptomatic.
- Pain and inflammation relief:
- NSAIDs (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs - e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) are often effective for mild to moderate pain and inflammation.
- Corticosteroids (e.g., oral prednisone) may be prescribed for more severe pain and inflammation, or if NSAIDs are not sufficient. Steroids are usually tapered slowly.
- For hyperthyroid symptoms (during thyrotoxic phase):

- Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) can help relieve symptoms like rapid heart rate, tremors, and anxiety. Antithyroid drugs (like methimazole) are NOT used as the thyroid is not overproducing new hormone, but leaking stored hormone.
- For hypothyroid symptoms (during hypothyroid phase):

- If symptoms are mild and phase is expected to be transient, no treatment may be needed. If symptoms are significant or TSH is very high, temporary thyroid hormone replacement (levothyroxine) may be given, and then gradually withdrawn as thyroid function recovers.
Rest as needed, especially if fatigued or have fever.
Avoid activities that put pressure on the neck if it's very tender.

Most people make a full recovery with normal thyroid function, but a small percentage may develop permanent hypothyroidism. Regular follow-up with thyroid function tests is important to monitor recovery and detect any long-term issues.

subarachnoid_hemorrhage.emergency_advice: A subarachnoid hemorrhage is a life-threatening type of stroke. Call emergency services (911, 999, 112) or go to the nearest emergency room immediately if someone experiences: a sudden, extremely severe headache, often described as 'the worst headache of my life' or a 'thunderclap headache' (peaks in intensity within seconds to minutes); nausea, vomiting; stiff neck (nuchal rigidity); sensitivity to light (photophobia); blurred or double vision; loss of consciousness (can be brief or prolonged); seizures; or neurological deficits (e.g., weakness, numbness, speech problems). Rapid diagnosis and treatment are critical to prevent re-bleeding and manage complications.
subarachnoid_hemorrhage.general_advice: A subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the brain and the thin membranes (meninges - specifically between arachnoid mater and pia mater) that cover the brain and spinal cord. This space normally contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). The most common cause of spontaneous (non-traumatic) SAH is the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm, which is a weak, bulging spot on an artery in the brain. Other causes can include: arteriovenous malformation (AVM - a tangle of abnormal blood vessels) rupture, head trauma (traumatic SAH is common), bleeding disorders or anticoagulant use, or rarely, certain types of brain tumors or infections. The bleeding irritates the brain and meninges, increases intracranial pressure, and can lead to brain damage, stroke (from vasospasm - narrowing of brain arteries, a common complication after SAH), hydrocephalus (fluid buildup in brain), seizures, and death. Re-bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm is a major risk in the early period.
subarachnoid_hemorrhage.when_to_see_doctor: Immediate emergency medical care in a hospital with neurosurgical and stroke capabilities is essential. Diagnosis is made with a CT scan of the head (can usually detect SAH quickly). If CT is negative but SAH is still highly suspected, a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) may be done to look for blood in the CSF. Cerebral angiography (catheter-based, CT angiography - CTA, or MR angiography - MRA) is then performed to identify the source of bleeding (e.g., aneurysm, AVM).
self_care_tips: Self-care is NOT for managing an acute SAH. It requires intensive hospital care, often in a neuro-ICU.
Emergency treatment aims to stabilize the patient, prevent re-bleeding, manage intracranial pressure, and treat complications.

- If a ruptured aneurysm is found: Urgent procedures to secure the aneurysm are needed, either by surgical clipping (open brain surgery to place a clip across neck of aneurysm) or endovascular coiling (catheter-based procedure to fill aneurysm with platinum coils to promote clotting). Choice depends on aneurysm location, size, shape, and patient factors.
- If AVM is cause: May involve embolization, surgery, or stereotactic radiosurgery.

- Medical management: Strict blood pressure control, medications to prevent vasospasm (e.g., nimodipine), pain management, anti-seizure medications if needed, management of hydrocephalus (e.g., ventricular drain or shunt), and supportive care.

Long-term recovery and rehabilitation (physical, occupational, speech, cognitive therapy) are often needed, as SAH can cause significant neurological and cognitive deficits. The severity of outcome depends on the initial bleed, re-bleeding, vasospasm, and other complications.

Prevention (for those at high risk of aneurysm rupture, e.g., strong family history, certain genetic conditions, or unruptured aneurysms found incidentally): Discuss screening and management options (observation vs. treatment) with a neurosurgeon/neurovascular specialist. Control blood pressure, quit smoking.

subconjunctival_hemorrhage.emergency_advice: While usually harmless, seek medical attention from an eye doctor if a subconjunctival hemorrhage: is associated with significant eye pain, vision changes (blurring, double vision), light sensitivity, or discharge; occurs after significant eye trauma or head injury (to rule out more serious internal eye injury or skull fracture); is very large or involves the entire white of the eye; is recurrent without obvious cause; or if you are on blood-thinning medication or have a bleeding disorder.
subconjunctival_hemorrhage.general_advice: A subconjunctival hemorrhage is a common, usually benign condition where a small blood vessel breaks just beneath the conjunctiva, the clear membrane that covers the white part of the eye (sclera). This causes blood to leak out and spread under the conjunctiva, resulting in a bright red or dark red patch on the white of the eye. It often looks alarming but is typically painless and does not affect vision. It's similar to a bruise on the skin. Causes can include: spontaneous rupture of a tiny blood vessel (often no known cause), straining (from coughing, sneezing, vomiting, heavy lifting, or constipation), eye rubbing, minor eye trauma, high blood pressure (though not a direct cause, can be associated), or use of blood-thinning medications (e.g., aspirin, warfarin, clopidogrel).
subconjunctival_hemorrhage.when_to_see_doctor: Most subconjunctival hemorrhages do not require medical treatment. However, if you have concerns or meet any of the emergency criteria, see an eye doctor. They can confirm the diagnosis and rule out other problems.
self_care_tips: There is no specific treatment to speed up the resolution of a subconjunctival hemorrhage. The blood will gradually be reabsorbed by the body over 1-3 weeks, similar to a bruise. The red patch may change color (e.g., to yellowish or greenish) as it heals.
Artificial tears (lubricating eye drops) may be used if there's mild irritation or a gritty sensation.
Avoid rubbing your eyes.
If caused by straining, try to address the underlying cause (e.g., manage constipation, control coughing).
If you are on blood thinners, inform your doctor who prescribes them, but do NOT stop your medication unless advised to do so.
If recurrent, your doctor may investigate for underlying causes like high blood pressure or bleeding tendencies (though often no specific cause is found for recurrences either).

subdural_hematoma.emergency_advice: A subdural hematoma, especially if acute or causing neurological symptoms, is a life-threatening neurosurgical emergency. Call emergency services (911, 999, 112) or go to the nearest emergency room immediately if someone experiences symptoms after a head injury (even a seemingly minor one, especially in elderly or those on blood thinners), or if symptoms develop gradually and suggest SDH. Symptoms can include: persistent or worsening headache, confusion, drowsiness, lethargy, personality changes, slurred speech, vision problems, dizziness, weakness or numbness on one side of body, seizures, or loss of consciousness. Rapid diagnosis and treatment are critical.
subdural_hematoma.general_advice: A subdural hematoma (SDH) is a collection of blood that forms between the dura mater (the tough outer membrane covering the brain) and the arachnoid mater (the membrane beneath the dura). It's usually caused by tearing of bridging veins that cross the subdural space, often due to head trauma. SDHs are classified based on onset: 1) Acute SDH: Develops rapidly (within hours to a few days) after severe head injury. Associated with significant brain injury and high mortality. Symptoms are often immediate and severe. 2) Subacute SDH: Develops more slowly (days to 2-3 weeks) after head injury. Symptoms may be less dramatic initially. 3) Chronic SDH: Develops very gradually (weeks to months) after a minor or sometimes even unrecognized head injury. More common in elderly individuals (due to brain atrophy, which stretches bridging veins, making them more vulnerable) and those on anticoagulant or antiplatelet medications. Symptoms can be subtle and insidious (e.g., progressive headache, confusion, memory problems, unsteadiness, weakness, personality changes), often mimicking dementia or stroke. The accumulating blood can compress brain tissue and increase intracranial pressure, leading to brain damage.
subdural_hematoma.when_to_see_doctor: Immediate emergency medical care is essential if an acute SDH is suspected, or if symptoms of chronic SDH develop. Diagnosis is made with a CT scan of the head (shows characteristic crescent-shaped hematoma) or MRI.
self_care_tips: Self-care is NOT for managing an SDH. It requires urgent neurosurgical evaluation and treatment.
Treatment depends on the size of the hematoma, severity of symptoms, whether it's acute or chronic, and patient's overall condition.
- For small, asymptomatic chronic SDHs: Careful observation with serial CT scans may be an option if stable.

- For symptomatic or larger acute/subacute/chronic SDHs: Surgical evacuation of the hematoma is usually necessary. This can be done via: burr holes (small holes drilled in skull to drain fluid blood), craniotomy (temporary removal of a bone flap to access and remove clot), or sometimes other techniques.
- Supportive care in hospital: Managing intracranial pressure, seizure prevention/treatment, neurological monitoring.
- Reversal of anticoagulation if applicable.

Recovery and prognosis depend on severity of initial injury, speed of treatment, and extent of any underlying brain damage. Rehabilitation (physical, occupational, speech, cognitive therapy) is often needed.
Prevention: Prevent head injuries (helmets, seatbelts, fall prevention for elderly). Cautious use of anticoagulants, especially in elderly or those at risk of falls.

substance_related_mental_disorder.display_name: Substance-Induced Mental Disorder (e.g., Substance-Induced Psychosis, Anxiety, Depression)
substance_related_mental_disorder.emergency_advice: Seek immediate emergency medical or psychiatric help if substance use or withdrawal leads to: acute psychosis (hallucinations, delusions, severe agitation, paranoia, disorganized behavior posing risk); severe depression with suicidal thoughts or attempts; severe anxiety or panic attacks that are incapacitating; delirium (acute confusion, disorientation, fluctuating consciousness); or if there are signs of severe intoxication or withdrawal that are medically dangerous (e.g., seizures, cardiovascular collapse, respiratory depression - see specific drug entries).
substance_related_mental_disorder.general_advice: A substance-induced mental disorder is a mental health condition (e.g., psychosis, mood disorder, anxiety disorder, delirium, sleep disorder, sexual dysfunction, neurocognitive disorder) where the symptoms are a direct physiological consequence of substance intoxication (current use), substance withdrawal (after stopping or reducing use), or medication use. The symptoms are typically more severe or persistent than the transient effects usually associated with intoxication or withdrawal for that substance, and cause clinically significant distress or impairment. Many different substances can induce mental disorders, including: Alcohol, Cannabis, Hallucinogens (LSD, psilocybin), Inhalants, Opioids, Sedatives/Hypnotics/Anxiolytics (benzodiazepines, barbiturates), Stimulants (cocaine, amphetamines, methamphetamine), Tobacco (withdrawal can cause irritability/anxiety/depression), Caffeine (intoxication/withdrawal can cause anxiety/sleep issues), and various prescription or over-the-counter medications (e.g., corticosteroids can induce mood changes/psychosis; some cold meds can cause agitation). The specific mental disorder induced depends on the substance and individual vulnerability. For example, stimulants can induce psychosis or anxiety; alcohol/sedative withdrawal can cause anxiety, delirium, or seizures; opioid withdrawal causes dysphoria/anxiety.
substance_related_mental_disorder.when_to_see_doctor: If you or someone you know is experiencing significant mental health symptoms that appear to be related to substance use or withdrawal, consult a doctor or mental health professional (psychiatrist, addiction specialist, therapist). It's crucial to get an accurate diagnosis, differentiate from a primary mental disorder, and address both the substance use and the mental health symptoms.
self_care_tips: Management involves addressing both the substance use and the induced mental disorder. Professional help is usually essential.
- Discontinuation of the offending substance is a primary goal (often requires detoxification and treatment for substance use disorder - see Drug Abuse entries).
- Treatment of the induced mental disorder:
- Symptoms often resolve or significantly improve once the substance is cleared from the body or withdrawal is complete. However, sometimes symptoms can persist.
- Supportive care during acute intoxication or withdrawal (may require hospitalization if severe).

- Medications may be used to manage acute symptoms (e.g., antipsychotics for substance-induced psychosis - often short-term; benzodiazepines for severe anxiety or agitation during withdrawal - used cautiously).
- Psychotherapy (e.g., CBT, motivational interviewing) to address substance use, develop coping skills, and manage mental health symptoms.
- Treat any co-occurring primary mental disorders if present.
Avoid the substance that triggered the disorder.
Build a strong support system.
Maintain a healthy lifestyle (sleep, diet, exercise) to support overall mental and physical health.
If prescribed medications known to have potential for inducing mental symptoms, be aware of this and report any concerns to your doctor.

syndrome_of_inappropriate_secretion_of_a.display_name: Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)
syndrome_of_inappropriate_secretion_of_a.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms of severe or rapidly developing hyponatremia (low blood sodium) occur due to SIADH: severe nausea, vomiting, headache, confusion, disorientation, extreme drowsiness or lethargy, muscle weakness or cramps, agitation, restlessness, seizures, or loss of consciousness. Severe hyponatremia can cause cerebral edema and is life-threatening.
syndrome_of_inappropriate_secretion_of_a.general_advice: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is a condition characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH, also called vasopressin) from the posterior pituitary gland (or from an abnormal source elsewhere in the body), or an increased kidney response to ADH, leading to impaired water excretion by the kidneys. ADH normally tells the kidneys to reabsorb water, concentrating urine and conserving body water. In SIADH, too much ADH causes the kidneys to reabsorb too much water, leading to water retention, dilution of body fluids, and a low blood sodium level (dilutional hyponatremia - see Hyponatremia entry). Urine is often inappropriately concentrated despite the low blood sodium. Causes of SIADH are numerous and can include: 1) Cancers (especially small cell lung cancer, which can produce ectopic ADH). 2) Central nervous system disorders (e.g., stroke, head trauma, brain tumors, infections like meningitis/encephalitis, hydrocephalus). 3) Lung diseases (e.g., pneumonia, tuberculosis, COPD, asthma). 4) Medications (many drugs can stimulate ADH release or enhance its action, e.g., certain antidepressants like SSRIs/TCAs, carbamazepine, cyclophosphamide, opioids, NSAIDs, ecstasy). 5) Major surgery or severe pain/stress. 6) Idiopathic (unknown cause). Symptoms are primarily those of hyponatremia and depend on severity and rapidity of onset. Mild, chronic hyponatremia may be asymptomatic or cause subtle symptoms. More significant or acute hyponatremia causes nausea, vomiting, headache, confusion, weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps, and can progress to seizures, coma (see emergency advice).
syndrome_of_inappropriate_secretion_of_a.when_to_see_doctor: If you have symptoms of hyponatremia or a condition known to be associated with SIADH, consult your doctor. Diagnosis of SIADH involves confirming hyponatremia (low serum sodium) with low serum osmolality, inappropriately concentrated urine (high urine osmolality relative to serum), normal kidney/adrenal/thyroid function, and euvolemia (normal body fluid volume status, or mild hypervolemia without edema). The underlying cause needs to be identified.
self_care_tips: Management is medically supervised and focuses on treating the underlying cause of SIADH (if possible) and correcting the hyponatremia slowly and carefully.
- Fluid restriction: Often the first-line treatment, limiting daily fluid intake (e.g., to 800-1000 mL/day) to help increase serum sodium.
- Increase solute intake: Sometimes oral salt tablets or urea may be given to help increase water excretion.
- Medications (for more severe or persistent hyponatremia, or if fluid restriction is not effective/tolerated):
- Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) may be used with salt tablets to increase free water excretion.

- Vasopressin receptor antagonists (vaptans - e.g., tolvaptan, conivaptan): Block the action of ADH on kidneys, promoting water excretion. Used cautiously, often in hospital setting, due to risk of too rapid correction or liver issues.
- Demeclocycline (an antibiotic that can inhibit ADH effect - less used now).

- For severe, symptomatic hyponatremia: Careful infusion of hypertonic saline (3% saline) in a hospital setting with frequent monitoring of sodium levels to correct it slowly (rapid correction can cause osmotic demyelination syndrome - a serious neurological complication).
Treat the underlying cause (e.g., treat infection, stop offending drug, manage cancer).
Monitor fluid intake and output, daily weights, and serum sodium levels regularly as advised by your doctor.
Be aware of medications that can cause SIADH.

syphilis.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for symptoms of neurosyphilis (especially if acute or severe - e.g., severe headache, stiff neck, fever, confusion, seizures, stroke-like symptoms, vision/hearing changes), cardiovascular syphilis (e.g., chest pain, shortness of breath, aortic aneurysm symptoms), or severe complications in congenital syphilis (in newborns). Gummas (late benign syphilis lesions) causing critical organ damage also need urgent care. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial at all stages to prevent irreversible damage.
syphilis.general_advice: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium *Treponema pallidum*. It progresses in stages if left untreated, and can affect many parts of the body. 1) Primary syphilis (3-90 days after exposure, average 21 days): Characterized by a chancre, which is usually a single, firm, painless, round sore or ulcer at the site of infection (genitals, anus, mouth, or lips). Chancre often heals on its own within 3-6 weeks, even without treatment, but infection persists. 2) Secondary syphilis (weeks to months after chancre heals, if untreated): Bacteria spread throughout body. Symptoms include a non-itchy skin rash (often on palms/soles, can be widespread), mucous membrane lesions (sores in mouth, vagina, anus), swollen lymph nodes, fever, sore throat, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, weight loss, and patchy hair loss. Symptoms also resolve without treatment, but infection continues. 3) Latent syphilis: After secondary stage symptoms disappear, syphilis enters a latent (hidden) stage where there are no symptoms, but infection is still present. Can last for years. Early latent (<1 year), late latent (>1 year). 4) Tertiary (late) syphilis (10-30 years after initial infection, if untreated, in about 15-40% of untreated): Can cause severe damage to heart and blood vessels (cardiovascular syphilis - e.g., aortitis, aortic aneurysm), brain and nervous system (neurosyphilis - e.g., meningitis, stroke, dementia/general paresis, tabes dorsalis - spinal cord degeneration), skin and bones (gummas - soft, tumor-like growths). Congenital syphilis occurs when a pregnant woman transmits syphilis to her fetus, which can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, premature birth, or severe health problems in the newborn. Syphilis is transmitted by direct contact with a chancre during sexual activity (vaginal, anal, oral) or from mother to baby during pregnancy/childbirth.
syphilis.when_to_see_doctor: If you have any sores, rash, or other symptoms suggestive of syphilis, or if you've had unprotected sex or a partner diagnosed with syphilis, get tested. Regular STI screening is important for sexually active individuals. Diagnosis involves blood tests (for antibodies - non-treponemal tests like VDRL/RPR for screening/monitoring, and treponemal tests like TP-PA/FTA-ABS for confirmation). Direct detection of bacteria from chancre fluid (dark-field microscopy or PCR) can also be done. Neurosyphilis diagnosis may involve lumbar puncture. Syphilis is treatable and curable with antibiotics, especially in early stages.
self_care_tips: If diagnosed with syphilis, take all prescribed antibiotics exactly as directed by your doctor. Penicillin (usually injectable penicillin G) is the preferred treatment for all stages. Dosage and duration depend on stage. For penicillin-allergic individuals, alternative antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline, tetracycline, ceftriaxone) may be used, but penicillin desensitization may be needed for neurosyphilis or syphilis in pregnancy.
Abstain from all sexual activity until you and all your sexual partner(s) have completed treatment and are cleared by a doctor.
Notify all sexual partners (from recent past - duration depends on stage of your syphilis) so they can be tested and treated. This is crucial to prevent reinfection and further spread.
Follow-up blood tests are necessary after treatment to ensure the infection has been cured (VDRL/RPR titers should decline).
Practice safe sex consistently (condoms) to reduce STI risk.
Get regular STI screenings if sexually active and at risk.
If pregnant, early screening and treatment for syphilis are vital to prevent congenital syphilis.

syringomyelia.emergency_advice: While syringomyelia is usually slowly progressive, seek immediate medical attention for: sudden, severe worsening of neurological symptoms (e.g., rapid onset of significant weakness, paralysis, severe pain, or loss of sensation); acute bowel or bladder dysfunction; or signs of acute hydrocephalus or brainstem compression if syrinx extends into brainstem (syringobulbia - e.g., difficulty breathing/swallowing, dizziness, facial numbness/weakness).
syringomyelia.general_advice: Syringomyelia is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled cyst or cavity (called a syrinx) within the spinal cord. Over time, this syrinx can expand and elongate, compressing or damaging nerve fibers in the spinal cord that transmit signals between the brain and the body. This can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, depending on the location and size of the syrinx. Most commonly, syringomyelia is associated with a Chiari I malformation, a condition where brain tissue (cerebellar tonsils) protrudes into the spinal canal, obstructing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow. Other causes can include: spinal cord trauma or injury, spinal cord tumors, meningitis or arachnoiditis (inflammation of membranes around spinal cord), tethered spinal cord syndrome, or idiopathic (unknown cause). Symptoms often develop gradually and may include: pain (often in neck, shoulders, arms, or back, can be burning, aching, or sharp), weakness and muscle atrophy (wasting) in arms and hands (often asymmetrical), stiffness in back, shoulders, arms, or legs, loss of sensation (especially to pain and temperature, often in a 'cape-like' distribution over shoulders/arms, while touch sensation may be preserved - 'dissociated sensory loss'), headaches, scoliosis (curvature of spine), and sometimes bowel/bladder dysfunction or problems with sweating or temperature regulation.
syringomyelia.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience persistent, unexplained pain, weakness, numbness, or other neurological symptoms suggestive of syringomyelia, consult your doctor (primary care or neurologist/neurosurgeon). Diagnosis is made with an MRI of the spine (and often brain, to look for Chiari malformation or other causes), which can visualize the syrinx.
self_care_tips: Management depends on the underlying cause, size of syrinx, severity of symptoms, and rate of progression. It's guided by a neurosurgeon and neurologist.
- Observation: If syrinx is small and asymptomatic or causing only mild, stable symptoms, regular MRI monitoring may be all that's needed.

- Treatment of underlying cause: If a Chiari malformation is present and thought to be causing the syrinx, surgical decompression of the Chiari (posterior fossa decompression) may be performed to restore normal CSF flow and potentially allow the syrinx to shrink or stabilize. If a tumor is the cause, removing the tumor may help.

- Surgical drainage or shunting of the syrinx: If the syrinx is large, progressive, or causing significant symptoms, and the underlying cause can't be effectively treated or if it persists after treating cause, surgery may be done to drain the syrinx directly (e.g., by creating a small opening - syringostomy, or by placing a shunt tube to divert fluid from syrinx to another body cavity like peritoneal or pleural space).
- Pain management: Medications for neuropathic pain (e.g., gabapentin, pregabalin, amitriptyline), NSAIDs, or other analgesics.
- Physical and occupational therapy: To maintain/improve strength, range of motion, function, and help with adaptive strategies for daily living if there are neurological deficits.
- Avoid activities that can increase pressure in the syrinx or spinal cord (e.g., heavy straining, activities with risk of spinal trauma - discuss with doctor).
Regular follow-up with MRI and neurological exams to monitor syrinx and symptoms.
Support groups for syringomyelia/Chiari can be helpful.

systemic_lupus_erythematosus_sle.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for acute, severe complications or flares of lupus: sudden, severe chest pain or shortness of breath (could be pleuritis, pericarditis, pulmonary embolism, or heart attack); signs of stroke (FAST symptoms); seizures or acute psychosis/confusion (neuropsychiatric lupus); rapidly declining kidney function (e.g., significant swelling, decreased urine output, severe fatigue - lupus nephritis flare); high fever with signs of severe infection (lupus patients are often on immunosuppressants); or severe, widespread rash with blistering or systemic illness.
systemic_lupus_erythematosus_sle.general_advice: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus, is a chronic autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own healthy tissues and organs. This can cause widespread inflammation and damage in various parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, heart, lungs, blood cells, and blood vessels. Lupus is characterized by periods of illness (flares) and periods of remission (when symptoms are less active). The cause is unknown but involves genetic predisposition, hormonal factors (more common in women, especially of childbearing age), and environmental triggers (e.g., sun exposure, infections, certain medications - drug-induced lupus). Symptoms are highly variable and can range from mild to life-threatening, depending on which body systems are affected. Common symptoms include: extreme fatigue, joint pain, stiffness, and swelling (arthritis), a characteristic butterfly-shaped rash (malar rash) across the cheeks and nose (though not everyone gets it), skin rashes that worsen with sun exposure (photosensitivity), fever, unexplained weight loss or gain, mouth sores (ulcers), hair loss (alopecia), Raynaud's phenomenon (fingers/toes turn white/blue and feel numb in cold/stress), chest pain (pleurisy or pericarditis), headaches, confusion, memory problems, and kidney problems (lupus nephritis - often no early symptoms, detected by urine/blood tests). Blood abnormalities (anemia, low white cells, low platelets) are also common.
systemic_lupus_erythematosus_sle.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience persistent, unexplained symptoms that could suggest lupus, especially a combination of fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and fever, consult your doctor (primary care or rheumatologist - specialist in autoimmune diseases). Diagnosis can be challenging as symptoms vary and mimic other conditions. It involves a medical history, physical exam, and blood/urine tests (e.g., antinuclear antibody - ANA test is often positive but not specific to lupus; more specific autoantibodies like anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm; complement levels; inflammatory markers; kidney/liver function, CBC). Criteria (e.g., from ACR/EULAR) are used to classify/diagnose.
self_care_tips: There is no cure for lupus, but treatments can help manage symptoms, control inflammation, prevent flares, and minimize organ damage. Management is lifelong and guided by a rheumatologist and other specialists if organs are involved.
- Medications:
- NSAIDs (for pain/inflammation - use with caution if kidney involvement).
- Antimalarials (e.g., hydroxychloroquine - Plaquenil): Mainstay for most lupus patients, helps with skin/joint symptoms, fatigue, reduces flares, and has long-term benefits.
- Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone): For flares and more severe disease, often tapered to lowest effective dose or discontinued if possible.
- Immunosuppressants (steroid-sparing agents, e.g., methotrexate, azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclophosphamide - for more severe organ involvement like lupus nephritis).
- Biologic agents (e.g., belimumab, anifrolumab, rituximab - for some types/severities of lupus).
- Lifestyle modifications:
- Sun protection: Crucial, as sun exposure can trigger flares and worsen rashes. Use broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30+), wear protective clothing, hats.
- Healthy diet: Balanced, anti-inflammatory diet.
- Regular exercise (as tolerated, low-impact): Can help with fatigue, joint stiffness, mood.
- Manage stress and ensure adequate rest/sleep.
- Quit smoking (smoking can worsen lupus and reduce treatment effectiveness).
- Regular monitoring of disease activity and organ function (blood/urine tests, specialist visits).
- Get recommended vaccinations (but discuss live vaccines with doctor if on immunosuppressants).
- Learn to recognize early signs of a flare and have an action plan.
- Support groups for lupus can provide valuable emotional support and information.

teething_syndrome.emergency_advice: While teething is a normal process, seek medical attention if an infant has a high fever (e.g., >101-102°F or 38.3-38.9°C), persistent vomiting or diarrhea, significant rash, or seems unusually ill, very irritable, or lethargic. These are generally NOT symptoms of teething and could indicate an underlying illness (like an ear infection or other infection) that needs evaluation.
teething_syndrome.general_advice: Teething syndrome refers to the cluster of mild symptoms that some infants and young children experience as their primary (baby) teeth erupt through the gums. This process usually begins around 4-7 months of age, but timing varies greatly. The lower front teeth (incisors) are often the first to appear. Symptoms of teething are usually mild and can include: irritability or fussiness, drooling (can be excessive), gum soreness, tenderness, and swelling, chewing or gnawing on objects, slightly elevated temperature (usually not a true fever - typically below 101°F/38.3°C), disrupted sleep patterns, changes in appetite (may refuse food or want to nurse/bottle-feed more for comfort), and sometimes a mild rash around the mouth from drooling. Teething does NOT typically cause high fever, vomiting, diarrhea, or significant illness.
teething_syndrome.when_to_see_doctor: Consult your pediatrician if you are concerned about your baby's teething symptoms, if symptoms are severe, if there's a high fever, or if you suspect another illness. They can confirm if it's likely teething and rule out other problems.
self_care_tips: Focus on relieving discomfort:
- Gum massage: Gently rub or massage your baby's gums with a clean finger or a moist gauze pad.

- Teething rings/toys: Offer a firm rubber teething ring or a clean, cool (not frozen solid, as that can be too hard/cold) washcloth to chew on. Chilling a teething ring in the refrigerator (not freezer) can provide extra soothing.
- Cool foods: If your baby is eating solids, cool, soft foods like applesauce or yogurt might be soothing.
- Wipe away drool frequently with a soft cloth to prevent skin irritation or rash around the mouth.

- Pain relievers (if needed and baby is uncomfortable, especially at night - use as directed by pediatrician): Acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin - for babies 6 months and older). Use correct dosage for baby's age/weight.

- Avoid over-the-counter topical teething gels or liquids containing benzocaine (an anesthetic) in infants and young children due to risk of a rare but serious side effect called methemoglobinemia. The FDA advises against their use. Also avoid homeopathic teething tablets/gels (some have been found to contain inconsistent amounts of belladonna, a toxic substance). Amber teething necklaces are not recommended due to choking and strangulation risks and lack of proven benefit.
Provide extra comfort and cuddles.

Maintain good oral hygiene once teeth erupt: Start cleaning baby's gums even before teeth appear with a soft, damp cloth. Once teeth erupt, brush with a soft infant toothbrush and a tiny smear (rice-grain size) of fluoride toothpaste (or as advised by dentist/pediatrician).

temporary_or_benign_blood_in_urine.display_name: Benign or Transient Hematuria (Blood in Urine)
temporary_or_benign_blood_in_urine.emergency_advice: While some causes of hematuria are benign, ANY new episode of visible blood in urine (gross hematuria) or persistent microscopic hematuria found on testing should be evaluated by a doctor to rule out serious underlying conditions. Seek urgent medical attention if hematuria is accompanied by: severe pain (e.g., flank pain - kidney stone, or severe bladder pain), inability to urinate, passage of large blood clots, fever/chills (infection), signs of significant blood loss (dizziness, weakness, pallor), or if it occurs after trauma.
temporary_or_benign_blood_in_urine.general_advice: Hematuria is the presence of red blood cells in the urine. It can be gross (visible to naked eye, urine appears pink, red, or cola-colored) or microscopic (blood cells only seen under microscope during urinalysis). Temporary or benign causes of hematuria can occur, meaning it's not due to a serious, progressive disease, and may resolve on its own or with minimal intervention. Potential benign/transient causes include: 1) Strenuous exercise: Can sometimes cause temporary hematuria, especially in runners ('marathonuria'). 2) Minor trauma or irritation to urinary tract. 3) Menstruation: Contamination of urine sample with menstrual blood in women. 4) Certain medications: e.g., some antibiotics (rifampin can turn urine orange-red, not true hematuria; cyclophosphamide can cause hemorrhagic cystitis), or anticoagulants (can unmask underlying minor bleeding). 5) Benign familial hematuria: An inherited condition causing persistent microscopic hematuria but usually no serious kidney problems. 6) Loin pain hematuria syndrome: Rare, causes flank pain and hematuria, cause unclear. 7) Sometimes a single episode of microscopic hematuria may have no identifiable cause and not recur. However, it's crucial to distinguish these from more serious causes like UTIs, kidney stones, kidney diseases (glomerulonephritis, polycystic kidney disease), bladder/kidney/prostate cancer, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), trauma, or bleeding disorders.
temporary_or_benign_blood_in_urine.when_to_see_doctor: All episodes of gross hematuria, and persistent or significant microscopic hematuria, require medical evaluation by a doctor (primary care, urologist, or nephrologist) to determine the cause. Diagnosis involves a urinalysis, urine culture (if infection suspected), blood tests (kidney function, CBC, clotting studies if needed), imaging (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI), and often cystoscopy (looking inside bladder with a scope) or ureteroscopy.
self_care_tips: Management depends entirely on the underlying cause, if one is identified.
- If due to strenuous exercise, it usually resolves with rest and hydration. Discuss with doctor if recurrent.
- If due to menstrual contamination, a repeat urinalysis when not menstruating is needed.
- If no serious cause is found after thorough evaluation and hematuria is transient or deemed benign, no specific treatment may be needed other than monitoring as advised by your doctor.
Stay well-hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids (water).
If a specific cause is found (e.g., UTI, kidney stone, BPH), that condition will be treated.
Do not ignore blood in urine; always get it checked out.

temporomandibular_joint_disorder.emergency_advice: While TMD is not usually an emergency, seek urgent medical attention if you experience: inability to open or close your jaw (locked jaw); suspected jaw dislocation or fracture after trauma; or severe, uncontrolled pain, especially if accompanied by fever or significant swelling (could indicate infection).
temporomandibular_joint_disorder.general_advice: Temporomandibular disorders (TMDs), often referred to as TMJ disorders or TMJ syndrome (TMJ actually refers to the joint itself), are a group of conditions that cause pain and dysfunction in the temporomandibular joints (the two joints connecting the lower jaw/mandible to the skull, located in front of each ear) and the muscles and ligaments that control jaw movement. Symptoms can vary widely and may include: pain or tenderness in the jaw joint area, face, neck, or shoulders (often worse with chewing, talking, or yawning); clicking, popping, or grating sounds (crepitus) in the jaw joint when opening or closing the mouth; difficulty opening or closing the mouth fully; locking of the jaw (getting 'stuck' open or closed); headaches (often tension-type); earaches or ringing in ears (tinnitus); dizziness; and sometimes changes in how upper and lower teeth fit together (malocclusion). The exact cause of TMD is often multifactorial and not always clear, but can involve: problems with the jaw muscles (myofascial pain), issues within the joint itself (e.g., disc displacement/derangement, arthritis - osteoarthritis/rheumatoid arthritis), trauma or injury to the jaw or TMJ, teeth grinding or clenching (bruxism - often stress-related or during sleep), stress, or dental problems affecting bite.
temporomandibular_joint_disorder.when_to_see_doctor: If you have persistent jaw pain, clicking, locking, or difficulty with jaw function, consult your doctor or dentist. They can evaluate your symptoms, examine your jaw, and may refer you to a specialist (e.g., TMJ specialist, oral and maxillofacial surgeon, or physical therapist specializing in TMD). Diagnosis is usually based on clinical exam and history. Imaging (X-rays, panoramic X-ray, CT, MRI) may be used in some cases to assess joint structure or rule out other conditions.
self_care_tips: Conservative, self-care measures are often effective for managing TMD symptoms:
- Eat soft foods. Avoid hard, chewy, sticky, or crunchy foods that require wide opening or forceful chewing (e.g., tough meats, bagels, gum, raw carrots). Cut food into small pieces.
- Avoid extreme jaw movements: Limit wide yawning, loud singing, shouting. Don't rest chin on hand.
- Apply moist heat or cold packs to the affected jaw area for 15-20 minutes several times a day (heat for muscle soreness/stiffness, cold for acute pain/inflammation).
- Practice stress management and relaxation techniques (deep breathing, meditation, yoga) as stress and jaw clenching often go together.
- Gentle jaw stretching and relaxation exercises (as guided by a doctor, dentist, or physical therapist). Be careful not to overstretch.
- Over-the-counter pain relievers: NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) or acetaminophen.
- Be aware of daytime jaw clenching or teeth grinding habits and try to consciously relax your jaw (lips together, teeth slightly apart).
Medical treatments (if self-care is not enough):
- Oral splint or mouth guard (night guard): A custom-fitted device worn over teeth (usually at night) to reduce clenching/grinding, relieve pressure on TMJ, and help jaw muscles relax.
- Prescription medications: Muscle relaxants, stronger pain relievers, anti-anxiety drugs, or antidepressants (for pain/bruxism).
- Physical therapy: Can include exercises, manual therapy, posture correction, and modalities.
- Injections: Corticosteroid injections into the TMJ for inflammation (used sparingly). Botulinum toxin (Botox) injections into jaw muscles for severe bruxism/muscle spasm.
- Dental work to correct bite problems if contributing.
- Rarely, arthrocentesis (flushing out joint), arthroscopy, or open joint surgery for severe, refractory cases with structural joint problems.

tendinitis.emergency_advice: While tendinitis is not usually an emergency, seek immediate medical attention if you experience: sudden, severe pain with inability to move the affected joint or limb, or a 'pop' or 'snap' sound at the time of injury, as this could indicate a complete tendon rupture (which may require urgent surgical repair). Also, if there are signs of infection around the tendon area (redness, warmth, swelling, fever).
tendinitis.general_advice: Tendinitis (also spelled tendonitis) is the inflammation of a tendon, which is a thick, fibrous cord that attaches muscle to bone. The term tendinopathy is often preferred now as many chronic tendon problems involve degeneration (tendinosis) with or without significant inflammation. Tendinitis/tendinopathy is usually caused by overuse, repetitive strain, or sudden injury to a tendon, leading to microtears, inflammation, and pain. It can occur in many parts of the body. Common types include: Rotator cuff tendinitis (shoulder - see separate entry), Biceps tendinitis (shoulder/upper arm), Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis - outer elbow, see separate entry), Golfer's elbow (medial epicondylitis - inner elbow), Patellar tendinitis ('jumper's knee' - below kneecap), Achilles tendinitis (back of heel/ankle), De Quervain's tenosynovitis (thumb side of wrist - see separate entry), and Wrist tendinitis. Symptoms typically include: pain or aching at the site of the affected tendon, often worse with movement or activity involving that tendon; tenderness to touch over the tendon; mild swelling or thickening of the tendon; and sometimes stiffness or reduced range of motion. Risk factors include age (tendons become less flexible), certain sports or occupations involving repetitive motions, improper technique or equipment, sudden increases in activity level, and some medical conditions (e.g., arthritis, diabetes).
tendinitis.when_to_see_doctor: If tendon pain is severe, persistent (lasts more than a few weeks despite self-care), or significantly limits your activity, consult your doctor (primary care, sports medicine, or orthopedist). They can diagnose the condition (usually by physical exam, sometimes with ultrasound or MRI if tear or other issues suspected) and recommend appropriate treatment.
self_care_tips: Conservative treatment is usually effective.
- Rest and activity modification: Avoid or reduce activities that cause pain or stress the affected tendon. This is crucial for healing.
- Ice: Apply cold packs for 15-20 minutes, several times a day, especially after activity or during acute pain, to reduce inflammation.
- Pain relievers: Over-the-counter NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) or acetaminophen. Topical NSAID gels/creams can also be helpful.
- Compression: An elastic wrap or supportive brace/strap may help reduce stress on the tendon and provide support (e.g., tennis elbow strap, wrist splint, ankle brace).
- Gentle stretching and range-of-motion exercises: Once acute pain subsides, to prevent stiffness.

- Eccentric strengthening exercises: Specific exercises where the muscle lengthens under tension (e.g., for Achilles or patellar tendinopathy) are often very effective for tendinopathy. A physical therapist can design a specific program.
- Gradual return to activity: Avoid returning too quickly or too intensely to prevent re-injury.
- Proper technique and ergonomics for sports/work activities. Ensure proper equipment.
Medical treatments (if conservative measures fail):
- Physical therapy: For specific exercise programs, manual therapy, and modalities.
- Corticosteroid injections near the tendon (used cautiously, as can sometimes weaken tendon if injected directly into it, especially for weight-bearing tendons like Achilles).
- Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injections or other regenerative medicine techniques (evidence still evolving).
- Rarely, surgery (e.g., to repair a severely damaged tendon or release pressure) for chronic, refractory cases.

tension_headache.emergency_advice: While tension headaches are usually not serious, seek immediate medical attention if you experience: a sudden, severe headache unlike any previous headache ('thunderclap headache'); headache with fever, stiff neck, confusion, seizures, or neurological symptoms (weakness, numbness, vision changes, slurred speech - to rule out meningitis, stroke, or other serious conditions); headache after a head injury; or a headache that is progressively worsening or changes significantly in pattern.
tension_headache.general_advice: Tension-type headache (TTH) is the most common type of primary headache (meaning not caused by an underlying medical condition). It's often described as a constant, dull ache or pressure, typically on both sides of the head (bilateral), often feeling like a tight band or vise around the head. The pain is usually mild to moderate in intensity and is generally not aggravated by routine physical activity (unlike migraine). Nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light (photophobia) or sound (phonophobia) are usually absent or mild if present (if prominent, consider migraine). TTH can be: 1) Episodic: Occurs less than 15 days per month. Can be infrequent (e.g., a few times a year) or frequent. 2) Chronic: Occurs 15 or more days per month for at least 3 months. Can be very disabling. The exact cause is not fully understood but may involve muscle tension in the neck, scalp, and shoulders, as well as changes in brain chemicals (like serotonin) and pain sensitivity. Common triggers include: stress, anxiety, depression, fatigue, poor posture (e.g., from prolonged computer use, 'text neck'), eye strain, hunger (skipping meals), dehydration, changes in sleep patterns, caffeine withdrawal, jaw clenching or teeth grinding (bruxism), and sometimes weather changes or certain smells.
tension_headache.when_to_see_doctor: If you have frequent or severe headaches, if they interfere with your daily life, if your headache pattern changes, or if you are concerned, consult your doctor. They can diagnose TTH based on your symptoms and headache history, and rule out other causes. Keeping a headache diary can be helpful. It's important to differentiate TTH from migraine or other headache types for appropriate management.
self_care_tips: For acute episodic tension headaches:

- Over-the-counter pain relievers: Acetaminophen (Tylenol), NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen, aspirin). Some OTC products combine pain relievers with caffeine (can be more effective for some, but be mindful of caffeine rebound if used too often). Do not overuse these medications, as this can lead to medication-overuse headache (rebound headache).
- Rest in a quiet, dark room.
- Apply a cold compress or warm pack to your head or neck.
- Gentle neck stretches or massage.
- Relaxation techniques (deep breathing, meditation).
Prevention and management of frequent or chronic TTH:
- Identify and manage triggers: Keep a headache diary to identify personal triggers and try to avoid or modify them.
- Stress management: Regular exercise, relaxation techniques, yoga, mindfulness, biofeedback, CBT.
- Improve posture: Be mindful of posture when sitting, standing, working. Ensure ergonomic workstation setup.
- Regular physical activity.
- Maintain a regular sleep schedule.
- Eat regular, balanced meals. Stay hydrated.
- Limit caffeine and alcohol.
- Physical therapy: For neck/shoulder muscle tension, posture correction, exercises.
- Acupuncture or massage therapy may help some.
- If bruxism is a factor, a dental night guard may help.

- Prescription medications (for frequent/chronic TTH, from doctor): Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline - often at low doses), or other preventive medications may be considered. Muscle relaxants are sometimes used short-term for acute muscle tension.
Avoid relying heavily on acute pain medications if headaches are frequent, due to risk of medication-overuse headache.

testicular_cancer.emergency_advice: While testicular cancer itself doesn't usually present as an acute emergency in early stages, seek urgent medical attention if you experience: sudden, severe testicular pain (could be due to bleeding into a tumor, or unrelated testicular torsion which is an emergency); or symptoms of advanced/metastatic disease that are acute and severe (e.g., severe back pain with neurological symptoms - spinal cord compression from mets; severe shortness of breath or coughing up blood - lung mets; severe abdominal pain). Any new, unexplained testicular lump or significant change should be evaluated promptly.
testicular_cancer.general_advice: Testicular cancer is cancer that develops in one or both testicles (testes), the male reproductive glands located inside the scrotum that produce sperm and testosterone. It's a relatively rare cancer overall, but it's the most common cancer in young men (typically ages 15-35, though can occur at any age). There are two main types of testicular cancer, based on the type of cell where they originate: 1) Germ cell tumors (GCTs - >90% of cases): Arise from germ cells (cells that produce sperm). Subtypes include seminomas (tend to be slower growing, more sensitive to radiation) and non-seminomas (e.g., embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, choriocarcinoma, teratoma - often grow more quickly and may be mixed). 2) Stromal tumors (rare): Arise from hormone-producing or supportive tissues of testes (e.g., Leydig cell tumors, Sertoli cell tumors). The most common symptom of testicular cancer is a painless lump or swelling in one testicle. Other symptoms can include: a feeling of heaviness in the scrotum, a dull ache or pain in the testicle, scrotum, groin, or lower abdomen, a change in the size or consistency of a testicle, or sometimes fluid collection in scrotum (hydrocele). In some cases, symptoms of metastatic disease may be the first sign (e.g., low back pain from retroperitoneal lymph node mets, cough/shortness of breath from lung mets, breast tenderness/enlargement - gynecomastia, due to hormone production by some tumors). Risk factors include: undescended testicle (cryptorchidism - even if surgically corrected), family history of testicular cancer, personal history of testicular cancer in other testicle, certain genetic conditions (e.g., Klinefelter syndrome), and possibly HIV infection. Testicular cancer is highly treatable and often curable, especially when detected and treated early.
testicular_cancer.when_to_see_doctor: If you notice any lump, swelling, pain, or other change in your testicles, consult your doctor (primary care or urologist) promptly. Don't delay. Diagnosis involves a physical exam, testicular ultrasound (key imaging test), blood tests for tumor markers (alpha-fetoprotein - AFP, human chorionic gonadotropin - hCG, lactate dehydrogenase - LDH), and if cancer is suspected, surgical removal of the entire affected testicle (radical inguinal orchiectomy) is usually done for both diagnosis (pathology of tumor) and primary treatment. A biopsy of the testicle before removal is generally NOT done due to risk of spreading cancer cells.
self_care_tips: Treatment depends on the type and stage of the cancer and is managed by a team including a urologist, medical oncologist, and sometimes radiation oncologist.
- Radical inguinal orchiectomy (removal of testicle and spermatic cord): Primary treatment for almost all testicular cancers.
- After orchiectomy, further treatment depends on pathology and staging:

- Surveillance (active monitoring): For some early-stage seminomas and non-seminomas, close follow-up with imaging and tumor markers may be an option, with further treatment given only if cancer recurs.

- Chemotherapy: Often used for non-seminomas if spread to lymph nodes or distant sites, or as adjuvant therapy for high-risk stage I. Also used for advanced seminomas. Common regimens include BEP (bleomycin, etoposide, cisplatin).
- Radiation therapy: Primarily used for seminomas, often to retroperitoneal lymph nodes if spread there, or sometimes as adjuvant therapy for stage I seminoma.

- Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection (RPLND): A major surgery to remove lymph nodes in back of abdomen where testicular cancer often spreads, may be done for non-seminomas (especially if lymph nodes are enlarged or if chemo doesn't eliminate them).
Perform regular testicular self-examination (TSE) - e.g., monthly - to become familiar with normal feel and detect any changes early. Best done after warm bath/shower when scrotum is relaxed.
Discuss sperm banking before treatment if fertility is a concern, as some treatments can affect fertility.
A testicular prosthesis can be implanted for cosmetic reasons if desired.
Follow up regularly with your oncology team for surveillance (tumor markers, imaging) as testicular cancer can recur, though cure rates are high.
Seek emotional and psychological support (counseling, support groups).

testicular_disorder.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for: sudden, severe testicular pain (could be testicular torsion - a surgical emergency, or severe epididymitis/orchitis); rapid, significant swelling of the scrotum, especially if painful or with fever; trauma to the testicles causing severe pain, swelling, or bruising; or a hard, painless lump within the testicle itself (could be testicular cancer - needs prompt evaluation).
testicular_disorder.general_advice: Testicular disorder is a broad term for any condition affecting one or both testicles (testes), the male reproductive glands located in the scrotum that produce sperm and testosterone. Common testicular disorders include: 1) Epididymitis/Orchitis: Inflammation/infection of epididymis and/or testicle (see separate entries). 2) Testicular torsion: Twisting of spermatic cord, cutting off blood supply to testicle (surgical emergency). 3) Hydrocele: Fluid collection around testicle (see separate entry). 4) Varicocele: Enlarged veins within scrotum (like varicose veins), can sometimes affect fertility or cause dull ache. 5) Spermatocele: Cyst in epididymis containing sperm (see separate entry). 6) Testicular cancer: Malignant tumor of testicle (see separate entry). 7) Undescended testicle (Cryptorchidism - see separate entry). 8) Testicular trauma/injury. 9) Hypogonadism (low testosterone production, can be primary - testicular problem, or secondary - pituitary/hypothalamus problem). Symptoms vary greatly depending on the specific disorder but can include: testicular pain (can be acute or chronic, sharp or dull), scrotal swelling or lump, redness or warmth of scrotum, changes in testicular size or consistency, feeling of heaviness in scrotum, and sometimes fever, urinary symptoms, or infertility.
testicular_disorder.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience any testicular pain, swelling, lump, or other changes in your testicles or scrotum, consult your doctor (primary care or urologist) promptly. Many testicular conditions are treatable, but some (like torsion or cancer) require urgent attention for best outcomes.
self_care_tips: Management is highly specific to the diagnosed testicular disorder.
- For infections (epididymitis/orchitis): Antibiotics, pain relief, scrotal support, rest.
- For testicular torsion: Immediate surgery to untwist testicle and fix it in place (orchiopexy) to prevent recurrence. If testicle is not viable, it's removed (orchiectomy).
- For hydrocele/spermatocele: Often observation if asymptomatic; surgery if large/bothersome.
- For varicocele: Often no treatment if asymptomatic; surgical repair or embolization if causing pain or infertility.
- For testicular cancer: Orchiectomy, often followed by chemotherapy, radiation, or RPLND depending on type/stage.
- For hypogonadism: Testosterone replacement therapy if appropriate.
