Seek immediate emergency medical attention if you experience: sudden onset of severe, colicky abdominal pain; abdominal distension (bloating/swelling); nausea and vomiting (may become bilious or fecal-smelling); inability to pass stool or gas (obstipation); and sometimes bloody stools or signs of shock (rapid heart rate, low blood pressure, confusion). Delay in treatment can lead to bowel gangrene, perforation, peritonitis, sepsis, and death.
volvulus.general_advice: A volvulus is a condition where a loop of intestine twists around itself and the mesentery (the tissue that supports it and contains its blood vessels), causing a bowel obstruction and potentially cutting off blood supply to the twisted segment (strangulation). This can lead to ischemia (lack of oxygen), necrosis (tissue death), and perforation if not corrected quickly. Volvulus can occur in different parts of the intestine: 1) Sigmoid volvulus: Most common type in adults, especially elderly or debilitated individuals, often associated with chronic constipation, high-fiber diet (in some populations), or institutionalization. The sigmoid colon (S-shaped part of lower colon) is redundant and mobile, predisposing it to twisting. 2) Cecal volvulus: Less common, often in younger to middle-aged adults, involves twisting of the cecum (beginning of large intestine) and sometimes terminal ileum. May be related to abnormal intestinal fixation. 3) Midgut volvulus: Most common in infants and young children, often associated with malrotation of the intestine (a congenital abnormality where intestines don't settle into their normal position during fetal development). This is a surgical emergency in newborns. 4) Gastric volvulus (stomach twists on itself - rare). Symptoms vary by location and severity but typically include acute abdominal pain, distension, vomiting, and constipation/obstipation (see emergency advice).
volvulus.when_to_see_doctor: Go to an emergency department immediately if volvulus is suspected. Diagnosis involves a physical exam, abdominal X-rays (may show characteristic signs like 'coffee bean' sign for sigmoid volvulus, or dilated loops of bowel), and often a CT scan of the abdomen/pelvis (can confirm diagnosis, show location of twist, assess for ischemia, and identify cause). A contrast enema may be used for sigmoid volvulus diagnosis and sometimes for non-surgical detorsion.
self_care_tips: Self-care is NOT for managing an acute volvulus; it requires urgent hospital care and often surgery.
Treatment aims to untwist (detorse) the bowel, restore blood flow, and prevent recurrence.

- For sigmoid volvulus: Sometimes non-surgical detorsion can be attempted via sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy (passing a scope to untwist the loop and decompress it with a rectal tube). However, recurrence is common, so elective surgical resection of the sigmoid colon is often recommended after successful detorsion to prevent it.

- For cecal volvulus and midgut volvulus: Usually require emergency surgery to untwist the bowel, assess its viability, resect any necrotic segment, and often perform procedures to fix the bowel in place to prevent recurrence (e.g., cecopexy for cecal volvulus, Ladd's procedure for malrotation/midgut volvulus).
- Supportive care includes: Bowel rest (NPO), IV fluids, NG tube for decompression, antibiotics.
If bowel is gangrenous, resection is necessary, and an ostomy (colostomy or ileostomy) may be created temporarily or permanently.
Preventing conditions that can predispose to volvulus (e.g., managing chronic constipation in elderly for sigmoid volvulus) may be helpful, but many causes are anatomical or congenital.

von_willebrand_disease.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for: uncontrolled or prolonged bleeding from any site (e.g., after injury, surgery, dental work, or spontaneously); very heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia) causing significant anemia or hemodynamic instability; signs of significant internal bleeding (e.g., severe abdominal/joint/muscle pain with swelling, blood in urine/stool, severe headache with neurological symptoms); or if preparing for surgery or an invasive procedure and have known or suspected vWD (to plan for appropriate management).
von_willebrand_disease.general_advice: Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. It's caused by a deficiency or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF), a blood protein that plays a crucial role in blood clotting (hemostasis). vWF helps platelets stick to blood vessel walls at sites of injury (platelet adhesion) and also carries and protects clotting factor VIII (FVIII - the factor deficient in hemophilia A). There are three main types of vWD, with varying severity: 1) Type 1 vWD (most common, ~75%): Mild to moderate quantitative deficiency of vWF (lower than normal levels of structurally normal vWF). Symptoms are usually mild (e.g., easy bruising, nosebleeds, gum bleeding, prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, heavy menstrual periods). 2) Type 2 vWD (~20-25%): Qualitative defect in vWF (vWF is present but doesn't function properly). Has several subtypes (2A, 2B, 2M, 2N) with different functional defects and bleeding patterns. Can be mild to moderate. 3) Type 3 vWD (rare, most severe): Severe quantitative deficiency of vWF (very little or no vWF produced), leading to very low FVIII levels as well. Symptoms are severe and can include spontaneous bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and muscles, similar to moderate/severe hemophilia. vWD is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern (Type 1, most Type 2) or autosomal recessive pattern (Type 3, some Type 2). Acquired vWD can also occur (rarely) due to other medical conditions or medications.
von_willebrand_disease.when_to_see_doctor: If you or your child experiences frequent or prolonged bleeding, easy bruising, heavy menstrual periods, or if there's a family history of a bleeding disorder, consult your doctor (primary care or hematologist). Diagnosis involves a panel of blood tests to measure vWF antigen levels, vWF activity (e.g., ristocetin cofactor activity - vWF:RCo), FVIII levels, and sometimes vWF multimer analysis or genetic testing to determine type/subtype.
self_care_tips: Management depends on the type and severity of vWD and is guided by a hematologist, often at a specialized bleeding disorder treatment center.
- For mild Type 1 vWD or minor bleeding episodes:

- Desmopressin (DDAVP): A synthetic hormone that can stimulate release of stored vWF and FVIII from endothelial cells. Given IV, subcutaneously, or as a nasal spray. Effective for most Type 1 and some Type 2. Tachyphylaxis (decreased effectiveness with repeated use) can occur.

- Antifibrinolytic agents (e.g., tranexamic acid, aminocaproic acid): Help stabilize clots and reduce bleeding, especially useful for mucosal bleeding (nose, mouth, menstrual) or before dental procedures.
- For more severe vWD (Type 3, some Type 2, or unresponsive Type 1) or for major bleeding/surgery:
- vWF-containing factor concentrates (plasma-derived or recombinant): Replace deficient or defective vWF and FVIII.
- Management of heavy menstrual bleeding: Hormonal contraceptives, tranexamic acid, DDAVP, or vWF concentrates.
Avoid medications that can increase bleeding risk (e.g., aspirin, NSAIDs) unless specifically approved by your hematologist.
Practice good dental hygiene. Inform dentist about vWD before procedures.
Wear a medical alert bracelet.
Take precautions to prevent injuries.
Genetic counseling for individuals and families.
For women with vWD, specific management plans for pregnancy and childbirth are needed.

vulvar_cancer.emergency_advice: While usually not an acute emergency in early stages, seek prompt medical attention for: significant, uncontrolled bleeding from a vulvar lesion; signs of severe infection of a vulvar lesion (e.g., rapidly spreading redness, warmth, pain, foul-smelling pus, fever); or severe pain unresponsive to usual measures. Any suspicious vulvar lesion needs timely evaluation.
vulvar_cancer.general_advice: Vulvar cancer is a rare type of cancer that occurs on the vulva, the external female genital organs, which include the labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, and perineum (area between vagina and anus). Most vulvar cancers (about 90%) are squamous cell carcinomas, arising from skin cells. Other rarer types include melanoma of the vulva, adenocarcinoma (e.g., from Bartholin's glands), sarcoma, or basal cell carcinoma. Vulvar cancer often develops slowly over many years, sometimes preceded by precancerous changes called vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN). Symptoms can include: persistent itching, pain, or tenderness in the vulvar area; a lump, bump, or wart-like growth on the vulva; thickened, raised, or discolored (red, white, or dark) patches of skin on the vulva; an open sore or ulcer that doesn't heal (especially if it bleeds); abnormal bleeding or discharge not related to menstruation; or pain during urination or intercourse. Risk factors include: older age (most common after 65), infection with certain high-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV - associated with many squamous cell vulvar cancers, especially in younger women), history of VIN, lichen sclerosus (a chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting vulva), smoking, weakened immune system (e.g., HIV), and history of other genital cancers (e.g., cervical cancer).
vulvar_cancer.when_to_see_doctor: If you notice any persistent changes in the skin of your vulva, such as a lump, sore, itching, pain, or discoloration, consult your doctor or gynecologist (or gynecologic oncologist) promptly. Diagnosis involves a pelvic exam (careful inspection of vulva) and a biopsy of any suspicious lesion. If cancer is found, further tests (e.g., imaging like CT/MRI/PET scan) may be done for staging.
self_care_tips: Treatment depends on the type, stage, and location of the cancer, as well as patient's overall health. It's managed by a gynecologic oncologist and often a multidisciplinary team.

- Surgery: Mainstay of treatment for most vulvar cancers. Options range from wide local excision (removing tumor and margin of healthy tissue) or simple vulvectomy (removing part of vulva) for early-stage cancers, to radical vulvectomy (removing entire vulva) with inguinal lymph node dissection (removal of groin lymph nodes) for more advanced cancers. Sentinel lymph node biopsy may be an option for some to assess lymph node spread.

- Radiation therapy: May be used before surgery (to shrink tumor), after surgery (to kill remaining cancer cells), as primary treatment (if surgery not feasible), or for palliative care. Often given with concurrent chemotherapy (chemoradiation) for locally advanced disease.
- Chemotherapy: May be used with radiation, or for advanced/metastatic vulvar cancer.
- Targeted therapy or Immunotherapy: Being investigated or used for some advanced/recurrent cases.
Prevention and early detection:
- HPV vaccination can prevent HPV infections that can lead to some vulvar cancers and VIN.
- Regular gynecological exams, including vulvar inspection.
- Be aware of vulvar area and report any changes to doctor.
- Quit smoking.
- Practice safe sex to reduce HPV risk.
- Promptly treat conditions like lichen sclerosus or VIN.

Post-treatment care involves: wound care, management of side effects (e.g., lymphedema in legs if groin nodes removed, sexual dysfunction, body image issues). Regular follow-up for surveillance is crucial.
Seek emotional and psychological support (counseling, support groups).

vulvar_disorder.display_name: Vulvar Disorder (General - Itching, Pain, Rash, Lesion)
vulvar_disorder.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for: sudden, severe vulvar pain; rapidly progressing swelling or blistering; uncontrolled bleeding; signs of severe infection (e.g., extensive redness, warmth, pus, foul odor, fever); or if a lesion is growing very rapidly, ulcerating, or looks suspicious for cancer.
vulvar_disorder.general_advice: Vulvar disorder is a broad term for any condition affecting the vulva, the external female genital organs (labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, mons pubis, perineum). These disorders can cause a wide range of symptoms, including itching (pruritus vulvae - very common), pain or soreness (vulvodynia - chronic vulvar pain without an identifiable cause, or pain from specific lesions), burning, redness, swelling, discharge, lumps, bumps, sores, ulcers, or changes in skin color or texture. Causes are diverse: 1) Infections: Yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis), bacterial infections (e.g., bacterial vaginosis can cause vulvar irritation from discharge), sexually transmitted infections (STIs - e.g., herpes, genital warts/HPV, syphilis, trichomoniasis), scabies, pubic lice. 2) Inflammatory skin conditions (dermatoses): Eczema/dermatitis (atopic, contact - from irritants like soaps/detergents/pads, or allergens), Lichen sclerosus (causes white, thinned, itchy, fragile skin, can lead to scarring/fusion), Lichen planus (can cause erosive, painful lesions), Psoriasis. 3) Benign growths: Cysts (e.g., Bartholin's cyst, sebaceous cyst), skin tags, angiomas, nevi (moles). 4) Precancerous changes (Vulvar Intraepithelial Neoplasia - VIN) or Vulvar cancer (see separate entry). 5) Hormonal changes: Atrophic vulvovaginitis (genitourinary syndrome of menopause - GSM) due to low estrogen, causing dryness, itching, irritation. 6) Neurological conditions: Pudendal neuralgia (nerve pain). 7) Trauma or irritation.
vulvar_disorder.when_to_see_doctor: If you have persistent or bothersome vulvar symptoms, consult your doctor or gynecologist (or dermatologist specializing in vulvar conditions). Accurate diagnosis is key for appropriate treatment. This involves a pelvic exam (careful inspection of vulva), and may include swabs for infection, skin biopsy of any suspicious lesion, or allergy testing.
self_care_tips: Management is highly specific to the diagnosed vulvar disorder.
General vulvar care tips (can help with irritation and prevent some issues):

- Gentle hygiene: Wash vulva daily with plain warm water or a mild, unscented, pH-neutral soap/cleanser. Avoid harsh soaps, bubble baths, feminine hygiene sprays, or douching (which is for vagina, not vulva, and generally not recommended). Pat dry gently.
- Wear loose-fitting, breathable cotton underwear. Avoid tight synthetic clothing.
- Change out of wet swimsuits or sweaty gym clothes promptly.
- Avoid known irritants or allergens (e.g., scented pads/tampons, harsh detergents for underwear).
- Use a bland, fragrance-free emollient or barrier cream (e.g., petroleum jelly, zinc oxide) if skin is dry or irritated (apply externally).
- For itching: Cool compresses or sitz baths (plain warm water) may soothe. Avoid scratching.
- If due to infection (yeast, BV, STI): Specific antimicrobial treatment (topical or oral) prescribed by doctor.

- If due to inflammatory dermatosis (lichen sclerosus, lichen planus, eczema): Topical corticosteroids (often potent ones for vulva, under medical supervision) or calcineurin inhibitors are mainstays.
- If due to atrophy/GSM: Vaginal moisturizers, lubricants, low-dose vaginal estrogen.
- For vulvodynia: Multimodal approach often needed (pelvic floor physical therapy, neuropathic pain medications, topical anesthetics, psychological therapies).
Perform regular vulvar self-examination to be aware of any changes and report to doctor.

vulvodynia.emergency_advice: While vulvodynia itself is a chronic pain condition and not usually an acute emergency, seek medical attention if pain becomes suddenly much worse, unbearable, or if there are signs of an acute infection or other new, concerning vulvar symptoms (e.g., unusual bleeding, rapidly growing lesion). Also, if distress from chronic pain leads to severe depression or suicidal thoughts, seek urgent mental health care.
vulvodynia.general_advice: Vulvodynia is defined as chronic vulvar pain or discomfort, often described as burning, stinging, irritation, rawness, or aching, lasting for at least 3 months, without an identifiable cause (such as infection, skin disease, or neurological disorder, though these need to be ruled out). The pain can be generalized (affecting the entire vulva) or localized (affecting a specific area, such as the vestibule - the area around the vaginal opening, formerly called vestibulodynia or vulvar vestibulitis syndrome). The pain can be constant or intermittent, and may be provoked by touch or pressure (e.g., during sexual intercourse - dyspareunia, tampon insertion, gynecological exam, tight clothing, prolonged sitting) or occur spontaneously. The exact cause of vulvodynia is not fully understood but is thought to be multifactorial, potentially involving: nerve injury or irritation (neuropathic pain), pelvic floor muscle dysfunction (hypertonicity/spasm), genetic predisposition, hormonal factors, localized inflammation, or altered pain processing in the central nervous system. It can significantly impact quality of life, sexual function, and psychological well-being.
vulvodynia.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience persistent vulvar pain or discomfort, consult your doctor or gynecologist (preferably one specializing in vulvovaginal disorders or chronic pelvic pain). Diagnosis of vulvodynia is one of exclusion, meaning other potential causes of vulvar pain must be ruled out through a thorough history, pelvic exam (including careful palpation with a cotton swab - 'Q-tip test' - to map painful areas), and sometimes tests for infection or skin biopsy. It can take time to get an accurate diagnosis.
self_care_tips: Management of vulvodynia is often multimodal, individualized, and aims to reduce pain and improve function. It may involve a combination of approaches:
- Vulvar care measures (to reduce irritation):
- Use mild, unscented, pH-neutral soaps or just water for cleansing vulva. Avoid harsh soaps, bubble baths, feminine hygiene sprays, scented pads/tampons, or douching.
- Wear loose-fitting, breathable cotton underwear. Avoid tight clothing.
- Pat dry gently after bathing. Avoid rubbing.
- Use soft, white, unscented toilet paper.
- Avoid known irritants or allergens.
- Apply cool compresses or take cool/lukewarm sitz baths for comfort.

- Pelvic floor physical therapy: Often very helpful, especially if muscle dysfunction is a factor. Involves techniques like myofascial release, trigger point therapy, biofeedback, and exercises to relax and retrain pelvic floor muscles.
- Topical medications (prescribed by doctor):
- Local anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine ointment or gel) applied before intercourse or for pain relief.
- Compounded creams containing medications like gabapentin, amitriptyline, or baclofen.
- Topical estrogen cream (if vulvovaginal atrophy is also present).
- Oral medications (prescribed by doctor, often for neuropathic pain):
- Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline - at low doses).
- Anticonvulsants (e.g., gabapentin, pregabalin).
- SNRIs (e.g., duloxetine, venlafaxine).
- Nerve blocks or trigger point injections: May be used in some cases.

- Psychotherapy/Counseling: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), mindfulness, sex therapy can help with coping strategies, pain management, addressing anxiety/depression, and improving sexual function and relationships.
- Stress management.
- Surgery (e.g., vestibulectomy for localized, provoked vestibulodynia) is rarely considered, only for very specific cases unresponsive to other treatments.
Be patient, as finding effective treatment can take time and trial. A multidisciplinary approach is often best. Support groups for vulvodynia can be helpful.

wernicke_korsakoff_syndrome.emergency_advice: Wernicke's encephalopathy (the acute phase) is a medical emergency requiring immediate treatment with high-dose intravenous thiamine to prevent progression to Korsakoff syndrome (chronic phase) and irreversible brain damage or death. Seek immediate emergency medical attention if someone (especially with risk factors like chronic alcoholism or severe malnutrition) develops acute onset of: confusion, ataxia (unsteady gait, poor coordination), and ophthalmoplegia (abnormal eye movements, e.g., nystagmus, paralysis of eye muscles, double vision). Not all three are always present. Any new, acute neurological or mental status changes in an at-risk individual warrant urgent care.
wernicke_korsakoff_syndrome.general_advice: Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (WKS) is a severe neurological disorder caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). It typically occurs in two stages, though they can overlap or Korsakoff can develop without a clearly recognized Wernicke's phase: 1) Wernicke's encephalopathy (WE): An acute, life-threatening but potentially reversible brain disorder characterized by the classic triad of confusion/altered mental status (disorientation, apathy, inattention), ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities like nystagmus, palsies of eye muscles, ptosis), and ataxia (unsteady gait, difficulty with coordination). Other symptoms can include drowsiness, stupor, or coma. If not treated promptly and adequately with thiamine, WE can lead to permanent brain damage or death, or progress to Korsakoff syndrome. 2) Korsakoff syndrome (KS, Korsakoff's psychosis): A chronic, often irreversible neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by severe anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and retrograde amnesia (loss of some past memories), confabulation (making up stories to fill memory gaps, not intentionally lying), apathy, lack of insight, and sometimes disorientation. Other cognitive functions may be relatively preserved. The most common cause of WKS is chronic alcohol abuse, which leads to thiamine deficiency through poor diet, impaired thiamine absorption/storage, and increased thiamine requirements. Other causes of severe thiamine deficiency leading to WKS include: severe malnutrition (e.g., from starvation, eating disorders, poverty), prolonged vomiting (e.g., hyperemesis gravidarum), bariatric surgery (if thiamine not supplemented), certain cancers, chemotherapy, dialysis, or critical illness.
wernicke_korsakoff_syndrome.when_to_see_doctor: Immediate emergency medical care is crucial if Wernicke's encephalopathy is suspected. For individuals with chronic memory problems and a history of alcohol abuse or other risk factors for thiamine deficiency, neurological and psychiatric evaluation is needed to diagnose Korsakoff syndrome and manage long-term care.
self_care_tips: Acute Wernicke's encephalopathy requires urgent hospital treatment:
- High-dose intravenous (IV) or intramuscular (IM) thiamine is given immediately, often for several days, followed by oral thiamine supplementation.
- Supportive care, including hydration, nutritional support, and management of any co-existing conditions (e.g., alcohol withdrawal, electrolyte imbalances, infections).
For Korsakoff syndrome (chronic phase):
- Thiamine supplementation (oral) should be continued long-term.
- Complete abstinence from alcohol is essential if alcohol abuse was the cause.
- Nutritional rehabilitation: A balanced diet.
- Cognitive rehabilitation and memory aids may help some individuals manage memory deficits, but significant improvement in severe amnesia is often limited.
- Supportive living environment may be necessary for those with severe cognitive impairment and inability to live independently.
- Treat co-occurring medical and psychiatric conditions.
Prevention is key:
- For individuals at risk of thiamine deficiency (e.g., chronic alcohol use, malnutrition, bariatric surgery patients), prophylactic thiamine supplementation is often recommended.
- Encourage adequate nutrition and thiamine intake (thiamine is found in whole grains, meat - especially pork, legumes, nuts, yeast).
- Moderate alcohol consumption or seek treatment for alcohol use disorder.

white_blood_cell_disease.emergency_advice: Emergency needs depend on the specific disorder and its severity. Seek immediate medical attention for: signs of severe, uncontrolled infection (high fever, chills, sepsis - if neutropenia or functional WBC defect); acute complications of leukemia or lymphoma (see separate entries - e.g., bleeding, severe anemia, tumor lysis syndrome, critical organ compression); or severe allergic/hypersensitivity reaction if eosinophilic disorder is involved and triggered. Any sudden, severe illness in someone with a known WBC disorder warrants urgent care.
white_blood_cell_disease.general_advice: White blood cell (WBC) disorder is a very broad term for any condition that affects the number or function of white blood cells (leukocytes), which are a crucial part of the immune system, defending the body against infection and disease. WBCs are produced in the bone marrow. There are several types of WBCs, including neutrophils, lymphocytes (B-cells, T-cells, NK cells), monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Disorders can involve: 1) Too few WBCs (Leukopenia): Neutropenia (low neutrophils - most common, increases risk of bacterial/fungal infections), Lymphopenia (low lymphocytes - increases risk of viral/fungal/parasitic infections, can be seen in HIV/AIDS, immunosuppression, some genetic disorders). Causes of leukopenia can be bone marrow problems (e.g., aplastic anemia, leukemia, MDS, chemotherapy/radiation, vitamin deficiencies), infections (some viral), autoimmune diseases, or certain medications. 2) Too many WBCs (Leukocytosis): Neutrophilia (high neutrophils - often due to infection, inflammation, stress, steroids, CML), Lymphocytosis (high lymphocytes - often due to viral infections like mono, CLL, ALL), Eosinophilia (high eosinophils - allergies, asthma, parasitic infections, certain skin diseases, eosinophilic disorders, some cancers), Monocytosis, Basophilia. Can be reactive (normal response to stimulus) or neoplastic (due to blood cancers like leukemia/lymphoma). 3) Functional WBC disorders: WBCs are present in normal or even high numbers but do not function properly, leading to impaired immunity (e.g., chronic granulomatous disease - CGD, leukocyte adhesion deficiency - LAD, Chédiak-Higashi syndrome - these are rare genetic disorders). Symptoms vary greatly depending on the specific disorder, type of WBC affected, and whether count is too high or too low, or function is impaired. Common signs can include recurrent or severe infections (if low or dysfunctional WBCs), fatigue, fever, easy bruising/bleeding (if platelets also affected, e.g., in leukemia), bone pain, swollen lymph nodes, or symptoms related to specific leukemias/lymphomas.
white_blood_cell_disease.when_to_see_doctor: If you have persistent symptoms like frequent/severe infections, unexplained fatigue, fever, bruising/bleeding, or swollen lymph nodes, or if a routine blood test (CBC with differential) shows abnormal WBC counts, consult your doctor (primary care or hematologist/oncologist/immunologist). Further tests (e.g., peripheral blood smear, bone marrow aspiration/biopsy, flow cytometry, genetic tests, tests for infection/inflammation) are needed to diagnose the specific WBC disorder.
self_care_tips: Management is highly specific to the diagnosed WBC disorder and is guided by a specialist.
- If due to infection: Treat the infection.
- If due to medication: Stop or adjust offending drug (under medical advice).

- If neutropenia: Growth factors (G-CSF like filgrastim) to stimulate neutrophil production, prophylactic antibiotics/antifungals if severe, infection prevention measures (good hygiene, avoid sick contacts, safe food handling).
- If leukemia/lymphoma: Chemotherapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy, stem cell transplant (see specific entries).
- If primary immunodeficiency with functional WBC defect: e.g., prophylactic antimicrobials, interferon-gamma for CGD, HSCT.
- If eosinophilic disorder: Corticosteroids, targeted therapies (e.g., anti-IL-5 biologics).
Follow your doctor's specific treatment plan.
Maintain good hygiene to prevent infections if immunocompromised.
Ensure good nutrition.
Get recommended vaccinations (discuss with doctor, as live vaccines may be contraindicated if severely immunocompromised).
Report any signs of infection or new/worsening symptoms promptly.

whooping_cough.emergency_advice: Whooping cough can be life-threatening, especially in infants under 6 months old. Seek immediate medical attention for an infant or child (or adult with severe symptoms) if they have: severe coughing spells that cause difficulty breathing, gasping for air, or turning blue/purple (cyanosis); vomiting after coughing spells (post-tussive emesis); periods of apnea (stopped breathing, especially in infants); extreme fatigue or lethargy; or signs of dehydration due to poor feeding/vomiting. Hospitalization is often needed for infants and those with severe disease.
whooping_cough.general_advice: Whooping cough, or pertussis, is a highly contagious respiratory tract infection caused by the bacterium *Bordetella pertussis*. It's characterized by severe, uncontrollable coughing fits, often ending with a high-pitched 'whoop' sound as the person gasps for air (though the 'whoop' may not be present, especially in infants or adults). The illness typically occurs in stages: 1) Catarrhal stage (1-2 weeks): Starts like a common cold with runny nose, low-grade fever, mild cough, and sometimes sneezing or watery eyes. Highly contagious during this stage. 2) Paroxysmal stage (1-6 weeks, can last up to 10 weeks): Cough becomes much more severe, occurring in violent, uncontrollable spasms (paroxysms), often many coughs in a row without a breath in between. Can cause vomiting after coughing, exhaustion, and the characteristic 'whoop.' Thick mucus may be expelled. 3) Convalescent stage (weeks to months): Cough gradually lessens in severity and frequency, but paroxysms can recur with subsequent respiratory infections. Pertussis can affect people of all ages, but is most dangerous for infants who are too young to be fully vaccinated, as they are at high risk for severe complications like pneumonia, seizures, brain damage (encephalopathy), apnea, and death. Immunity from childhood vaccination wanes over time, so adolescents and adults can also get pertussis and can transmit it to vulnerable infants.
whooping_cough.when_to_see_doctor: If you or your child has a persistent, severe cough, especially if it occurs in fits or is followed by a 'whoop' sound or vomiting, consult your doctor. Diagnosis is often clinical, especially during an outbreak. A nasopharyngeal swab or aspirate can be tested for *B. pertussis* by culture or PCR (most sensitive, especially early in illness). Blood tests for antibodies may be used later. Early treatment with antibiotics is important to reduce severity, prevent spread, and reduce risk of complications (though antibiotics may not significantly alter course of illness if started late in paroxysmal stage).
self_care_tips: Pertussis requires treatment with antibiotics (usually macrolides like azithromycin, clarithromycin, or erythromycin; or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole if macrolide allergy/intolerance). Take the full course as prescribed. Antibiotics help make the person non-contagious (usually after 5 days of treatment) and can lessen symptoms if started early.

Prophylactic antibiotics may also be recommended for close contacts (e.g., household members, childcare contacts) to prevent them from getting sick, especially if there are vulnerable infants or high-risk individuals in the household.
Supportive care (especially for infants/young children, may require hospitalization):
- Keep home environment calm and free of irritants that can trigger coughing (smoke, dust, fumes).
- Encourage small, frequent meals and fluids to prevent dehydration and vomiting.
- Use a cool-mist humidifier to soothe airways.
- Monitor for signs of breathing difficulty or complications.
- Oxygen therapy or respiratory support if needed in hospital.
Prevention is key:

- Vaccination: Pertussis vaccine is part of routine childhood immunizations (DTaP - diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis). Booster doses (Tdap) are recommended for preteens/adolescents and adults (including a dose during each pregnancy for women, to protect newborn). Ensure all family members and caregivers of infants are up to date with Tdap.
- Practice good hygiene (handwashing, cover coughs).

wilson_disease.emergency_advice: Seek immediate medical attention for acute, life-threatening complications of Wilson's disease: acute liver failure (jaundice, confusion, ascites, bleeding, coagulopathy); severe, rapidly progressive neurological symptoms (e.g., severe dystonia, parkinsonism, seizures, coma); or acute hemolytic anemia (can occur with rapid copper release from liver). Untreated Wilson's disease is fatal.
wilson_disease.general_advice: Wilson's disease is a rare inherited (autosomal recessive) genetic disorder that causes an excessive accumulation of copper in the body, primarily in the liver, brain, eyes, and other organs. It's caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which is responsible for a protein that helps transport copper out of liver cells into bile (for excretion) and incorporate it into ceruloplasmin (a copper-carrying protein in blood). When this protein doesn't function properly, copper builds up to toxic levels, causing tissue damage. Symptoms usually begin between ages 5 and 35, but can range from early childhood to older adulthood. Manifestations vary widely: 1) Liver disease: Can range from asymptomatic elevated liver enzymes to acute hepatitis, chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, or acute liver failure. Symptoms may include fatigue, abdominal pain, jaundice, ascites, edema, easy bruising/bleeding. 2) Neurological symptoms: Due to copper deposition in brain (especially basal ganglia). Can include tremor (often a 'wing-beating' tremor of arms), dystonia (involuntary muscle contractions causing abnormal postures/movements), dysarthria (slurred speech), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), parkinsonism (rigidity, bradykinesia, gait problems), clumsiness, incoordination (ataxia), drooling, and changes in handwriting. 3) Psychiatric symptoms: Personality changes, depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder, psychosis, cognitive impairment. 4) Eye manifestation: Kayser-Fleischer rings - golden-brown or greenish rings around the edge of the cornea (where iris meets sclera), due to copper deposits. Visible on slit-lamp exam, sometimes to naked eye. Not always present, especially in early liver disease. 5) Other potential problems: Hemolytic anemia, kidney stones or kidney dysfunction, bone/joint problems (arthritis, osteoporosis), heart problems (cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias), or hormonal issues.
wilson_disease.when_to_see_doctor: If there is a family history of Wilson's disease, or if a child or adult develops unexplained liver disease, neurological or psychiatric symptoms (especially with movement disorders or personality changes), or Kayser-Fleischer rings, consult a doctor (pediatrician, primary care, gastroenterologist/hepatologist, neurologist, or geneticist). Early diagnosis and lifelong treatment are crucial to prevent irreversible organ damage. Diagnosis involves blood tests (serum ceruloplasmin - usually low, serum copper - can be low, normal, or high), 24-hour urine copper excretion (usually high), liver biopsy (to measure copper content and assess liver damage), eye exam (for Kayser-Fleischer rings), and genetic testing for ATP7B mutations.
self_care_tips: Wilson's disease requires lifelong medical treatment to remove excess copper and prevent re-accumulation. It's managed by specialists.

- Chelating agents: Medications that bind to copper and promote its excretion in urine. Common initial treatment drugs include D-penicillamine or trientine. These can have side effects and require careful monitoring.

- Zinc salts (e.g., zinc acetate, zinc sulfate): Used for maintenance therapy after initial chelation, or sometimes as initial treatment in asymptomatic or presymptomatic individuals. Zinc blocks copper absorption from the gut.

- Dietary modifications: Avoid or limit foods very high in copper, such as liver, shellfish (oysters, lobster), nuts (cashews, Brazil nuts), chocolate, mushrooms, and dried fruits. However, diet alone is not sufficient to control copper levels; medication is essential. Avoid copper-containing supplements or vitamin/mineral preparations. Check if drinking water has high copper content (e.g., from copper pipes - let water run before using).
- Liver transplant: May be necessary for acute liver failure or end-stage liver disease/cirrhosis unresponsive to medical therapy. Transplant also corrects the underlying metabolic defect.
Strict adherence to prescribed medication regimen is vital for life.
Regular monitoring of copper levels (urine, blood), liver function, neurological status, and for medication side effects.
Genetic counseling for the individual and family members (siblings should be screened).
Avoid alcohol (can worsen liver damage).
Support groups for Wilson's disease can be helpful.

yeast_infection.emergency_advice: While most common yeast infections (skin, oral, vaginal) are not emergencies, seek urgent medical attention if: an infection is very severe, widespread, not responding to treatment, or if you have a weakened immune system (e.g., HIV/AIDS, on chemotherapy or immunosuppressants) and develop signs of a potentially invasive or disseminated Candida infection (e.g., high fever, chills, sepsis, organ dysfunction). Also, severe oral thrush causing inability to eat/drink needs care.
yeast_infection.general_advice: Yeast infection, or candidiasis, is a fungal infection caused by an overgrowth of a type of yeast (fungus) called *Candida*, most commonly *Candida albicans*. Candida normally lives in small amounts on the skin, in the mouth, gastrointestinal tract, and vagina without causing problems. However, certain factors can disrupt the normal balance of microorganisms or weaken the immune system, allowing Candida to multiply excessively and cause infection. Common types of yeast infections include: 1) Oral thrush (Oral candidiasis - see separate entry): White patches in mouth, soreness. 2) Vaginal yeast infection (Vulvovaginal candidiasis - see separate entry): Itching, irritation, thick white discharge. 3) Cutaneous candidiasis (Skin): Affects skin folds (intertrigo - see separate entry, e.g., armpits, groin, under breasts, diaper area - diaper candidiasis) causing red, itchy rash, sometimes with satellite pustules. Can also affect nail folds (paronychia) or nails (onychomycosis - less common for Candida alone). 4) Invasive candidiasis (Systemic): Rare but serious, occurs when Candida enters bloodstream and spreads to internal organs (e.g., heart, brain, eyes, bones, kidneys). Usually affects hospitalized, critically ill, or severely immunocompromised individuals. Risk factors for yeast infections include: antibiotic use, corticosteroid use (oral or inhaled), weakened immune system, diabetes (especially poorly controlled), pregnancy, hormonal contraceptives with high estrogen, obesity, warm/moist environments, wearing tight/non-breathable clothing, poor hygiene (or sometimes over-cleansing with harsh products), and denture wear (for oral thrush).
yeast_infection.when_to_see_doctor: If you suspect a yeast infection, consult your doctor or dermatologist/gynecologist, especially if it's your first time, if symptoms are severe, recurrent, or don't improve with over-the-counter (OTC) treatments, or if you have underlying risk factors. Diagnosis is often clinical, but may involve microscopy (KOH prep) or culture of scrapings/swabs.
self_care_tips: Treatment depends on the location and severity of infection.

- For skin yeast infections: Topical antifungal creams, ointments, or powders (e.g., clotrimazole, miconazole, nystatin, ketoconazole - many available OTC). Keep affected area clean and dry. Wear loose, breathable clothing.
- For oral thrush: Topical antifungal mouth rinses, lozenges, or oral tablets (see Oral Thrush entry).

- For vaginal yeast infections: Topical antifungal suppositories/creams (OTC or prescription) or oral antifungal tablets (e.g., fluconazole - prescription or OTC in some regions) (see Vaginal Yeast Infection entry).
- For invasive candidiasis: Requires potent intravenous (IV) antifungal medications in hospital.
Prevention:
- Keep skin folds clean and dry.
- Wear breathable clothing.
- Change out of wet/sweaty clothes promptly.
- For oral thrush: Good oral hygiene, rinse mouth after inhaled steroids, clean dentures properly.
- For vaginal yeast infections: Cotton underwear, avoid douching/irritants.
- Manage underlying conditions like diabetes (good blood sugar control).
- Probiotics (yogurt with live cultures, supplements) may help maintain healthy balance of flora for some, but evidence varies (not a treatment for active infection).
Take full course of antifungal medication as prescribed.

zenker_diverticulum.emergency_advice: While Zenker's diverticulum itself usually develops slowly, seek immediate medical attention for acute complications: aspiration pneumonia (cough, fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, after regurgitating food/fluid into lungs); complete esophageal obstruction (inability to swallow anything, including saliva); or rarely, perforation of the diverticulum (severe neck/chest pain, fever, difficulty breathing - a surgical emergency). Significant malnutrition or weight loss due to swallowing difficulties also needs urgent evaluation.
zenker_diverticulum.general_advice: A Zenker's diverticulum is a rare type of outpouching (diverticulum) that forms in the pharynx (throat), just above the upper esophageal sphincter (UES - the muscle at the top of the esophagus that relaxes to allow swallowing). It occurs in an area of natural muscular weakness called Killian's triangle. It's considered a 'false' diverticulum as it involves only the mucosal and submucosal layers protruding through the muscle layer. Zenker's diverticulum is thought to develop due to increased pressure in the pharynx, often related to impaired relaxation or spasm of the UES (cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction) and/or discoordination of swallowing. This pressure causes the pharyngeal lining to bulge outwards over time, forming a pouch. It typically affects older adults (usually over 60-70). As the pouch enlarges, food and liquids can get trapped in it. Symptoms often develop gradually and can include: dysphagia (difficulty swallowing, often with a sensation of food sticking in the throat, especially solids), regurgitation of undigested food (sometimes hours after eating, or when lying down/bending over), coughing or choking spells (especially after swallowing or when lying down, due to aspiration of pouch contents), halitosis (bad breath from retained food), gurgling noises in the neck, unexplained weight loss or malnutrition, and recurrent aspiration pneumonia. A palpable neck mass is rare.
zenker_diverticulum.when_to_see_doctor: If you experience persistent difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, or other symptoms suggestive of a Zenker's diverticulum, consult your doctor (primary care or ENT specialist/gastroenterologist). Diagnosis is usually made with a barium swallow X-ray (esophagram), which can clearly visualize the pouch. Upper GI endoscopy may also be done (with caution, as scope can inadvertently enter diverticulum and cause perforation). Esophageal manometry may assess UES function.
self_care_tips: Management depends on the size of the diverticulum and severity of symptoms.
- For small, asymptomatic diverticula found incidentally: No specific treatment may be needed other than observation.
- For symptomatic diverticula: Treatment is usually surgical or endoscopic to relieve symptoms and prevent complications.

- Endoscopic techniques (minimally invasive, often preferred for smaller diverticula or older/frailer patients): e.g., endoscopic diverticulotomy or diverticulostomy (using a stapler or laser to cut the common wall between the diverticulum and esophagus, effectively incorporating pouch into esophagus and often cutting cricopharyngeus muscle - cricopharyngeal myotomy). Done via a scope through mouth.

- Open surgical repair (less common now for primary treatment, may be needed for very large or recurrent diverticula): Involves a neck incision to either remove the diverticulum (diverticulectomy) or suspend it (diverticulopexy), often combined with a cricopharyngeal myotomy (cutting the UES muscle to relieve pressure).
Dietary and behavioral modifications (may help mild symptoms or while awaiting treatment):
- Eat small, frequent meals.
- Chew food thoroughly and eat slowly.
- Choose soft, moist foods. Avoid dry, crumbly, or bulky foods that are hard to swallow.
- Drink fluids with meals to help food pass.
- Sit upright when eating and for a while afterwards. Avoid lying down immediately after meals.
- Try to empty the pouch after eating by turning head or pressing on neck (if taught by doctor).
- Good oral hygiene to manage bad breath.
If aspiration is a risk, speech therapy may provide swallowing strategies.
Follow your doctor's specific recommendations.
